src: 音符どおりに正確に奏でながら、手をできるだけリラックスした状態で保つようにしましょう。また、指が余計な動きをしないように努めましょう。 そうすることで、疲れがたまりにくくなります。ピアノのように音量を出すために力を入れて鍵盤を叩く必要はないことを覚えておいてください。 アコーディオンを弾くときに音量を上げるには、蛇腹を強く、または速く動かします。
mt: 1. Play the notes exactly as written, and keep your hands as relaxed as possible. Try not to move your fingers unnecessarily. This will help you avoid fatigue. Remember that you don't need to hit the keys hard or fast to make the instrument louder. 2. To increase the volume, you can either move the bellows more forcefully or faster.
ref: Make sure your hand is as relaxed as possible while still hitting all the notes correctly - also try not to make much extraneous motion with your fingers. This way, you will tire yourself out as little as possible. Remember there's no need to hit the keys with a lot of force for extra volume like on the piano. On the accordion, to get extra volume, you use the bellows with more pressure or speed.

src: 音符どおりに正確に奏でながら、手をできるだけリラックスした状態で保つようにしましょう。また、指が余計な動きをしないように努めましょう。 そうすることで、疲れがたまりにくくなります。ピアノのように音量を出すために力を入れて鍵盤を叩く必要はないことを覚えておいてください。 アコーディオンを弾くときに音量を上げるには、蛇腹を強く、または速く動かします。
mt: 1. Play the notes exactly as written, and keep your hands as relaxed as possible. Try not to move your fingers unnecessarily. This will help you avoid fatigue. Remember that you don't need to hit the keys hard or fast to make the instrument louder. 2. To increase the volume, you can either move the bellows more forcefully or faster.
ref: Make sure your hand is as relaxed as possible while still hitting all the notes correctly - also try not to make much extraneous motion with your fingers. This way, you will tire yourself out as little as possible. Remember there's no need to hit the keys with a lot of force for extra volume like on the piano. On the accordion, to get extra volume, you use the bellows with more pressure or speed.

src: 映画をDVD形式に変換しようとするときに最も一般的な問題の1つはオーバースキャンです。 ほとんどのテレビ番組は、大衆が喜ぶように製作されています。 そのため、テレビに映る映像すべての上下左右の境界線がカットされていました。 これは、画像が画面全体を確実に覆うようにできています。これをオーバースキャンといいます。 残念なことに、DVDを自作すると、境界がカットされる可能性が非常に高く、字幕が下に寄りすぎていると完全には表示されないでしょう。
mt: One of the most common problems when converting a movie to DVD format is overscan. Most television programs are produced in a way that pleases the masses. As a result, the borders of the image that appears on the television are cut off. This is done so that the image covers the entire screen. This is called overscan. Unfortunately, when you make your own DVD, the borders are likely to be cut off, and the subtitles may not be fully displayed at the bottom.
ref: One of the most common problems when trying to convert a movie to DVD format is the overscan. Most televisions are made in a way to please the general public. For that reason, everything you see on the TV had the borders cut, top, bottom and sides. This is made to ensure that the image covers the whole screen. That is called overscan. Unfortunately, when you make a DVD, it's borders will most likely be cut too, and if the video had subtitles too close to the bottom, they won't be fully shown.

src: アメリカの計画は、異なる3方向から協調攻撃を開始するというものでした。 ジョン・カドワルダー将軍は、敵の増援を阻止するために、ボーデンタウンにある英国軍駐屯地に向けて陽動攻撃を開始しました。 ジェームズ・ユーイング将軍は、トレントン軽巡洋艦で民兵700人を連れて川を渡り、アサンピンク・クリークにかかる橋を奪取し、敵軍の逃亡を阻止しました。 2,400人の主力突撃部隊は、トレントンの北9マイルの地点で川を渡り、グリーン指揮下とサリヴァン指揮下の2つの部隊に分かれ、夜明け前の攻撃を開始しました。
mt: The American plan was to begin coordinated attacks from three different directions. General John Cadwalader began a diversionary attack against the British garrison at Bordentown to prevent reinforcements. General James Ewing crossed the river with 700 militiamen aboard the Trenton frigate and captured the bridge over Assunpink Creek, blocking the enemy's retreat. A main force of 2,400 men crossed the river 9 miles north of Trenton and split into two groups under Greene and Sullivan, beginning their attack before dawn.
ref: The American plan relied on launching coordinated attacks from three different directions. General John Cadwalder would launch a diversionary attack against the British garrison at Bordentown, in order to block off any reinforcements. General James Ewing would take 700 militia across the river at Trenton Ferry, seize the bridge over the Assunpink Creek and prevent any enemy troops from escaping. The main assault force of 2,400 men would cross the river nine miles north of Trenton, and then split into two groups, one under Greene and one under Sullivan, in order to launch a pre-dawn attack.

src: 7月4日に議会で採択された後、ジョン・ハンコック大統領とチャールズ・トムソン長官が署名した手書きの草案が、数街区先のジョン・ダンラップ社の印刷所に送られました。 一晩で150～200枚が複製され、現在では「ダンラップ・ブロードサイド」と呼ばれています。 この文書の初の公開朗読は、7月8日に独立記念館の庭でジョン・ニクソンによって行われました。 1通は7月6日にジョージ・ワシントンに送られ、7月9日にニューヨークで軍隊に向けて朗読されました。もう1通は8月10日にロンドンに届きました。 現存することが知られている25枚のダンラップ・ブロードサイドは、現存する当該文献の最古の写しです。手書きによる原本は現存していません。
mt: After its passage in Congress on July 4, a handwritten draft signed by President John Hancock and Secretary of State Charles Thomson was sent to the John Dunlap print shop, a few blocks away. One hundred and fifty to two hundred copies were printed overnight, and are now known as the Dunlap Broadside. The first public reading of the document was by John Nixon at the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8. One copy was sent to George Washington on July 6, and read to the troops in New York on July 9. Another copy was sent to London on August 10. Of the 25 known Dunlap Broadside copies, the handwritten original does not survive.
ref: "After its adoption by Congress on July 4, a handwritten draft signed by the President of Congress John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent a few blocks away to the printing shop of John Dunlap. Through the night between 150 and 200 copies were made, now known as ""Dunlap broadsides"". The first public reading of the document was by John Nixon in the yard of Independence Hall on July 8. One was sent to George Washington on July 6, who had it read to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10. The 25 Dunlap broadsides still known to exist are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original handwritten copy has not survived."

src: この活動を見た入植者たちも増援を要請していた。 前方陣地を補強する部隊には、ジョン・スターク大佐とジェームズ・リード大佐（ともに後に将軍となる）の下で200人からなるニューハンプシャー第1連隊と第3連隊が動員されていました。 スタークの兵士たちは入植者陣地の北端側フェンス沿いに陣地を構えました。 干潮時に半島の北東に沿ってミスティック川に沿って隙間が開くと、彼らはすかさず、狭い海岸の北端まで低い石垣でフェンスを拡張しました。 グリッドリーまたはスタークは外柵の前方約100フィート(30 m)の位置に杭を打ち、正規軍がそこを通過するまで誰も発砲しないようにと命令しました。
mt: The settlers also requested reinforcements. The New Hampshire 1st and 3rd Regiments, under the command of Colonels John Stark and James Reed (both later generals), were mobilized to strengthen the front line. Stark's soldiers built a line along the fence at the northern end of the settlement. When the tide receded, they immediately extended the low stone wall along the narrow northern tip of the peninsula, along the Mystic River. Gridley or Stark ordered that no one fire until the regulars passed the line of stakes about 100 feet (30 m) in front of the outer fence.
ref: The Colonists, seeing this activity, had also called for reinforcements. Troops reinforcing the forward positions included the 1st and 3rd New Hampshire regiments of 200 men, under Colonels John Stark and James Reed (both later became generals). Stark's men took positions along the fence on the north end of the Colonist's position. When low tide opened a gap along the Mystic River along the northeast of the peninsula, they quickly extended the fence with a short stone wall to the north ending at the water's edge on a small beach. Gridley or Stark placed a stake about 100 feet (30 m) in front of the fence and ordered that no one fire until the regulars passed it.

src: 古代中国には、時代差を示す独自の方法があり、中国史における各段階、または権力を握っていた一族が特徴的な王朝となりました。 また、各王朝の間には、分断された地方の不安定な時代がありました。これらの時代のうち最もよく知られているのは、漢と晋の時代に挟まれ、60年間にわたって続いた三国時代です。 こうした時代には、王位をめぐって多くの貴族たちが激しい戦いを繰り広げていました。 三国志は、古代中国の歴史の中で最も血なまぐさい時代の1つでした。西安の大宮殿の最高位を狙う争いの中で何千人もが戦士しました。
mt: In ancient China, there was a unique way to show the difference in time, and the stages of Chinese history, or the family that held power became a characteristic dynasty. In between the dynasties, there were unstable times of division in the local areas. One of the most well-known of these times was the Three Kingdoms period, which lasted for 60 years between the Han and Jin dynasties. In these times, many nobles fought fiercely over the throne. The Romance of the Three Kingdoms was one of the most bloody times in the history of ancient China, where thousands of warriors fought for the highest position in the palace in Xian.
ref: Ancient China had a unique way of showing different time periods; each stage of China or each family that was in power was a distinctive dynasty. Also between each dynasty was an unstable age of divided provinces. The best-known of these periods was the Three Kingdoms epoch taking place for 60 years between the Han and the Jin Dynasty. During these periods fierce warfare took place between many nobles fighting for the throne. The Three Kingdoms was one of the bloodiest eras in Ancient China’s history thousands of people died fighting to sit in the highest seat in the grand palace at Xi’an.

src: 軍隊アリの群れは隊列を組んで移動し、巣の作り方も異なります。 遊牧段階では、軍隊アリは夜間に隊列を組んで移動し、日中は野営します。 コロニーでは、入手可能な食料が減少したときに遊牧を開始します。この時期、コロニーは一時的の巣を作り、毎日のように作り変えます。 こうした遊牧段階での暴挙や進撃は、約17日間ずつ続きます。
mt: Ant colonies form lines and build differently. During nomadic stages, army ants form lines at night and camp during the day. During colony stages, nomadic stages begin when food is scarce. During these nomadic stages, colonies build temporary nests and change them daily. These nomadic stages last about 17 days.
ref: Army ant colonies march and nest in different phases as well. In the nomadic phase, army ants march at night and stop to camp during the day. The colony begins a nomadic phase when available food has decreased. During this phase, the colony makes temporary nests that are changed everyday. Each of these nomadic rampages or marches lasts for approximately 17 days.

src: 生理学や行動で観察されるリズムの多くは、内因性周期の存在と体内時計を通して刻まれるしくみに決定的に依存していることが多いのです。 周期的リズムは、単に外部からの周期的な合図への応答ではなく、細菌、真菌、植物、動物を含むほとんどの生物について記録されています。 体内時計は、外部からの合図がなくても、一定期間、自由に循環し続ける自立的発振器です。
mt: Many of the rhythms observed in physiology and behavior are determined by the existence of endogenous cycles and the internal clock through which they are marked. Rhythms are not just responses to periodic cues from the outside, but have been recorded in most organisms, including bacteria, fungi, plants, and animals. The internal clock is an autonomous oscillator that continues to circulate freely for a certain period of time without external cues.
ref: Many observed rhythms in physiology and behavior often crucially depend on the presence of endogenous cycles and their production through biological clocks. Periodic rhythms, which are not simply responses to external periodic cues, have been documented for most living beings, including bacteria, fungi, plants, and animals. Biological clocks are self sustaining oscillators which will continue a period of free-running cycling even in the absence of external cues.

src: 集団とは、ある地理的な範囲にいる特定の種の生物の集まりです。 集団内のすべての個体が特定の表現形質に関して同一である場合、それらは単形性と呼ばれます。 個体が特定の形質を持つ何とおりもの変種として現れるとき、それらは多型質と呼ばれます。
mt: A population is a group of individuals of a particular species living in a particular geographic area. If all individuals in a population are identical with respect to a particular trait, they are said to be monomorphic. If individuals of a population are present in different forms, they are said to be polymorphic.
ref: A population is the collection of organisms of a particular species within a given geographic area. When all individuals in a population are identical with regard to a particular phenotypic trait they are known as monomorphic. When the individuals show several variants of a particular trait they are polymorphic.

src: 集団とは、ある地理的な範囲にいる特定の種の生物の集まりです。 集団内のすべての個体が特定の表現形質に関して同一である場合、それらは単形性と呼ばれます。 個体が特定の形質を持つ何とおりもの変種として現れるとき、それらは多型質と呼ばれます。

If all individuals in a population are identical with respect to a particular trait, they are said to be monomorphic. If individuals of a population are present in different forms, they are said to be polymorphic.
ref: A population is the collection of organisms of a particular species within a given geographic area. When all individuals in a population are identical with regard to a particular phenotypic trait they are known as monomorphic. When the individuals show several variants of a particular trait they are polymorphic.

src: 自然との触れあいを重視した観光は、野生の動植物を含めた景観を楽しむ目的で自然地域を訪れることに興味を持つ人々を魅了しています。 現地での活動の例としては、狩猟、釣り、写真撮影、バードウォッチング、公園の見学や生態系に関する情報調査などが挙げられます。 例としては、ボルネオ島のオランウータンに会いに行き、写真を撮ったり、学んだりすることが挙げられます。
mt: Nature-based tourism is a type of tourism that focuses on the interaction with nature. It is a type of tourism that involves visiting natural areas for the purpose of enjoying the landscape, including wildlife. Examples of activities in the area include hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, park visits, and ecological information gathering. For example, you can go to Borneo Island to see orangutans, take pictures, and learn about them.
ref: Nature-based tourism attracts people interested in visiting natural areas for the purpose of enjoying the scenery, including plant and animal wildlife. Examples of on-site activities include hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, and visiting parks and studying information about the ecosystem. An example is visiting, photographing, and learning about organgatuangs in Borneo.

src: 毎朝、小さな田舎町を出発して職場に向かう人々は、自分たちの出発地付近に職場がある人たちとすれ違います。 このダイナミックな往復輸送においては、誰もが自家用車をベースにした輸送系と何らかの形でつながり、それを支えています。 科学は今、この大規模な炭素経済によって、過去200万年間にわたって人間の進化を支えてきたその安定した状態の1つから生物圏を外したことを示しています。
mt: Every morning, people who live in small towns leave their homes and head to work, passing people who live in those towns and work in those towns. In this dynamic two-way commute, everyone is connected to some form of transportation system based on the private car, and that system is supported by that stable state of the biosphere that has been supporting human evolution for the past 200,000 years, one of the many stable states that the biosphere has been in.
ref: Every morning, people leave small country towns in cars to go their workplace and are passed by others whose work destination is the place they have just left. In this dynamic transport shuttle everyone is somehow connected with, and supporting, a transport system based on private cars. Science now indicates that this massive carbon economy has dislodged the biosphere from one of its stable states that has supported human evolution for the past two million years.

src: 原子は、すべての物質の基本的な構成要素の1つであると考えることができます。 これは非常に複雑な天体で、単純化されたボーアモデルによれば、中心核が電子によって周回しており、太陽を周回している惑星に似ています（図1.1参照）。 核はいずれも中性子と陽子という2つの粒子で構成されます。 陽子は正電荷を帯び、中性子は無電荷です。電子は負電荷を帯びた粒子です。
mt: An atom is one of the basic building blocks of all matter. This is a very complex celestial body, simplified in the Bohr model, where the nucleus is orbited by electrons, similar to planets orbiting the sun (see Figure 1.1). Nuclei are composed of two particles, neutrons and protons. Protons have a positive charge, neutrons are neutral. Electrons have a negative charge.
ref: The atom can be considered to be one of the fundamental building blocks of all matter. Its a very complex entity which consists, according to a simplified Bohr model, of a central nucleus orbited by electrons, somewhat similar to planets orbiting the sun - see Figure 1.1. The nucleus consists of two particles - neutrons and protons. Protons have a positive electric charge while neutrons have no charge. The electrons have a negative electric charge.

Nuclei are composed of two particles, neutrons and protons. Protons have a positive charge, neutrons are neutral. Electrons have a negative charge.
ref: The atom can be considered to be one of the fundamental building blocks of all matter. Its a very complex entity which consists, according to a simplified Bohr model, of a central nucleus orbited by electrons, somewhat similar to planets orbiting the sun - see Figure 1.1. The nucleus consists of two particles - neutrons and protons. Protons have a positive electric charge while neutrons have no charge. The electrons have a negative electric charge.

src: 事実上、今日使用されているすべてのコンピュータは、2進数で符号化された情報の操作に基づいています。 2進数は、2つの値 (0または1) のいずれかで表され、コンピュータ用語を使用するために、これらの数値は2進数またはビットと呼ばれます。
mt: 2進数は、2つの値 (0または1) のいずれかで表され、コンピュータ用語を使用するために、これらの数値は2進数またはビットと呼ばれます。
ref: Virtually all computers in use today are based on the manipulation of information which is coded in the form of binary numbers. A binary number can have only one of two values, i.e. 0 or 1, and these numbers are referred to as binary digits - or bits, to use computer jargon.

src: 事実上、今日使用されているすべてのコンピュータは、2進数で符号化された情報の操作に基づいています。 2進数は、2つの値 (0または1) のいずれかで表され、コンピュータ用語を使用するために、これらの数値は2進数またはビットと呼ばれます。
mt: 2進数は、2つの値 (0または1) のいずれかで表され、コンピュータ用語を使用するために、これらの数値は2進数またはビットと呼ばれます。
ref: Virtually all computers in use today are based on the manipulation of information which is coded in the form of binary numbers. A binary number can have only one of two values, i.e. 0 or 1, and these numbers are referred to as binary digits - or bits, to use computer jargon.

src: ブログは生徒の文章力を向上させるのにも役立ちます。ブログを書き始めたばかりの学生は文法もつづりもいい加減になりがちですが、読み手がいることでそこに変化が生まれます。 学生は最も批判的な読み手であることが多いので、ブログの書き手は批判を避けるために文章を改善しようとする努力を始めます。 また、ブログを書くことは、「学生たちを取り巻く世界についてより精通できるようにしてしまうのです。」 聴衆の興味を引きつける必要性によって、学生をより賢く、興味深い人物へと成長させます(Toto, 2004)。 ブログは共同作業を促進し、従来の授業の範囲を越えて学習の幅を広げるように学生たちに奨励するツールです。 ブログを適切に使用することで、「学生たちの分析力や批判力が向上する。インターネット素材に積極的に対応することで、学生たちは他者が書いた文脈で自己の立場を定義し、具体的な問題について自己の見解を示すことができる」（Oravec, 2002）。
mt: Blogs can help improve students' writing skills. Students who are just starting to write blogs often make mistakes in grammar and spelling, but with readers, changes can be made. Students are often the most critical readers, so to avoid criticism, they start to improve their writing. Also, blogging can promote collaboration and expand the scope of learning beyond the traditional classroom. By using blogs appropriately, "students' analytical and critical thinking skills are enhanced. By actively engaging with Internet materials, students are able to define their position in the context of others' writing and to express their views on specific issues" (Oravec, 2002).
ref: "Blogs can also help improve student writing. While students often begin their blog experience with sloppy grammar and spelling, the presence of an audience generally changes that. Since students are often the most critical audience, the blog writer begins to strive to improve writing to avoid criticism. Also blogging ""forces students to become more savvy about the world around them."" The need to feed the interest of the audience inspires students to be clever and interesting (Toto, 2004). Blogging is a tool that inspires collaboration, and encourages students to extend learning well beyond the traditional school day. Appropriate use of blogs ""can empower students to become more analytical and critical; through actively responding to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of others' writings as well as outline their own perspectives on particular issues (Oravec, 2002)."

src: 非同期コミュニケーションは、内省や他者への反応の時間を促すものです。 生徒は自分のペースで取り組むことができ、指導情報のペースをコントロールできます。 また、フレックスタイム制も可能で、時間的な制約が減ります。(Bremer, 1998) インターネットやウェブを利用することで、学習者はいつでも情報にアクセスできるようになります。 また、学生はいつでも講師に質問でき、次回の面談まで待たなくても、かなり迅速な返答を期待することができます。
mt: Asynchronous communication allows students to work at their own pace, controlling the pace of the instructional information.  It also allows for flex time, reducing time constraints.  (Bremer, 1998)  Students can access information at any time and can ask questions of the instructor at any time, expecting a fairly quick response.
ref: Asynchronous communication encourages time for reflection and reaction to others. It allows students the ability to work at their own pace and control the pace of instructional information. In addition, there are fewer time restrictions with the possibility of flexible working hours. (Bremer, 1998) The use of the Internet and the World Wide Web allows learners to have access to information at all times. Students can also submit questions to instructors at any time of day and expect reasonably quick responses, rather than waiting until the next face-to-face meeting.

src: 伝統的な中世の城は、長い間人々の想像力を掻き立て、馬上槍試合、酒宴、アーサー王の騎士の姿を彷彿とさせます。 千年の歴史を持つ遺跡iに囲まれて立っているだけで、遠い昔の戦いの音や匂いが思い浮かび、石畳を打つひづめの音が聞こえ、地下牢の穴から恐怖の匂いを嗅いが立ち上るような気がします。 しかし、私たちの想像力は現実に基づいているのでしょうか。そもそも城はなぜ作られたのでしょうか。どのように設計され、建設されたのでしょうか。
mt: Traditional medieval castles have long stirred the imagination, conjuring up images of jousting knights, feasts, and the Knights of the Round Table. Just standing in the shadow of a thousand-year-old ruin, you can almost hear the sounds and smells of ancient battles, the clink of swords on stone, and the stench of fear rising from the dungeon's pit. But is our imagination based in reality? Why were castles built in the first place? How were they designed and constructed?
ref: The traditional medieval castle has long inspired the imagination, conjuring up images of jousts, banquets and Arthurian chivalry. Even standing amidst thousand year-old ruins it is easy to bring to mind the sounds and smells of battles long gone, to almost hear the clatter of hooves on the cobbles and to smell the fear rising from the dungeon pits. But is our imagination based on reality? Why were castles built in the first place? How were they designed and built?

src: この時代の典型的な城であるカービー・マクスロー城は、お城というよりも要塞化された邸宅のような雰囲気を醸し出しています。 その大きなガラス窓と薄い壁では、長期にわたる断固たる攻撃に抗いきれなかったことでしょう。 ヘイスティングス卿によって建設が開始された1480年代には、この国は比較的平和であり、防衛が必要とされたのは、放浪する襲撃者の小集団から国を守るための防衛のみであった。
mt: This typical castle of the era, Kirby Muxloe, has the feel of a fortified manor house rather than a castle. Its large glass windows and thin walls would not have been able to withstand a sustained assault. In the 1480s, when the building was begun by Lord Hastings, the country was relatively peaceful and the defence was only needed to protect the country from small bands of marauders.
ref: Typical for the period, Kirby Muxloe Castle is more of a fortified house than a true castle. Its large glazed windows and thin walls would not have been able to resist a determined attack for long. In the 1480s, when its construction was begun by Lord Hastings, the country was relatively peaceful and defense was only required against small bands of roving marauders.

src: クォーターマラソンからハーフマラソンに転向する場合、スピードの重要性ははるかに低くなり、持久力が絶対的に必要になります。 もちろん、2分を切る一流のハーフランナーは、それなりのスピードがあるはずですが、どんなことがあっても持久力を伸ばしていかなければなりません。 冬場にクロスカントリー走をしながら、ジムに通って上半身を鍛えれば、ランニングシーズンに向けて最高の準備となります。
mt: When converting from a quarter marathon to a half marathon, speed becomes much less important and endurance becomes absolutely necessary. Of course, elite half marathoners who can run under 2 hours will have some speed, but they will still need to build endurance. Cross country running in the winter and going to the gym to work on upper body strength will prepare you best for the running season.
ref: With the change from the quarter to the half mile run, speed becomes of much less importance and endurance becomes an absolute necessity. Of course a first-class half-miler, a man who can beat two minutes, must be possessed of a fair amount of speed, but endurance must be cultivated at all hazards. Some cross country running during the winter, combined with gymnasium work for the upper part of the body, is the best preparation for the running season.

src: 栄養療法だけで超一流選手が育つわけではありませんが、栄養摂取は若い選手の健康状態全般を大きく左右する可能性があります。 健康的なエネルギーバランスを維持し、効果的な水分補給習慣を実践し、サプリメントのさまざまな実用面を理解することは、選手の成績向上にもスポーツの普及にも役立ちます。
mt: While nutrition alone does not make a super elite athlete, maintaining a healthy energy balance, effective hydration habits, and understanding the various practical aspects of supplements can help improve performance and promote sports participation.
ref: Proper nutritional practices alone cannot generate elite performances, but they can significantly affect young athletes' overall wellness. Maintaining a healthy energy balance, practicing effective hydration habits, and understanding the various aspects of supplementation practices can help athletes improve their performance and increase their enjoyment of the sport.

src: 中距離走は比較的安上がりなスポーツですが、参加に必要な装備が少ないという誤解が多いようです。 必要に応じて製品を購入できますが、性能に影響する製品はほとんどありません。 アスリートは、実質的なメリットがない製品でも好ましいと感じることがあります。
mt: Middle-distance running is relatively inexpensive, but many people believe that it requires little equipment. You can buy products as needed, but most products have little effect on performance. Athletes may feel good about products that have no real benefits.
ref: Middle distance running is a relatively inexpensive sport; however, there are many misconceptions regarding the few pieces of equipment required to participate. Products can be purchased as needed, but most will have little or no real impact on performance. Athletes may feel that they prefer a product even when it provides no real benefits.

src: MRIは、1930年代にフェリックス・ブロッホ（スタンフォード大学勤務）とエドワード・パーセル（ハーバード大学出身）によって発見された核磁気共鳴（NMR）と呼ばれる物理現象に基づく撮像法です。 この共鳴では、磁場と電波の作用で原子が微小な電波を発します。 1970年、医学博士であり研究者でもあるレイモンド・ダマディアン氏は、磁気共鳴画像を医学診断の道具として利用するための根拠を発見しました。 4年後には、MRIの分野で世界初となる特許が認められました。 1977年にダマディアン博士は世界初の「全身」MRI撮影装置を完成し、難題に立ち向かう自らの精神にちなんでその装置に「不屈」と名付けました。
mt: MRI is based on the nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) phenomenon discovered in the 1930s by Felix Bloch (Stanford University) and Edward Purcell (Harvard University). This resonance involves microscopic radio waves emitted by atoms under the influence of a magnetic field. In 1970, Raymond Damadian, a physician and researcher, discovered the basis for using magnetic resonance imaging as a medical diagnostic tool. Four years later, Damadian was granted the first patent in the field of MRI. In 1977, Damadian completed the first "whole-body" MRI scanner and named it "Indomitable" after his own indomitable spirit.
ref: MRI is based on a physics phenomenon called nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), which was discovered in the 1930s by Felix Bloch (working at Stanford University) and Edward Purcell (from Harvard University). In this resonance, magnetic field and radio waves cause atoms to give off tiny radio signals. In the year 1970, Raymond Damadian, a medical doctor and research scientist, discovered the basis for using magnetic resonance imaging as a tool for medical diagnosis. Four years later a patent was granted, which was the world's first patent issued in the field of MRI. In 1977, Dr. Damadian completed the construction of the first “whole-body” MRI scanner, which he called the ”Indomitable”.

src: 人間は他人の心を読むという点では、圧倒的に最も優秀な種である。 つまり、自分以外の人間が何を認識し、何を考え、何を信じ、何を知り、何を望んでいるかを予測できるということです。 これらの能力の中でも、他人の意図を理解することは非常に重要です。それにより、起こり得る物理的な行動における曖昧さを解決することができます。 例えば、車の窓を割っている人を見かけたら、他人の車を盗もうとしていると思うことでしょう。 車の鍵を紛失し、自分の車に侵入しようとしている人だとしたら、別の判断をする必要があるでしょう。
mt: Humans are by far the most adept at reading the minds of others, meaning that we can predict what other humans recognize, think, believe, know, and want. Of these abilities, understanding the intentions of others is particularly important, as it allows us to resolve ambiguities in physical actions. For example, if you see someone breaking a car window, you might think they are trying to steal a car. If you see someone trying to break into your car, you might make a different judgment.
ref: Humans are by far the most talented species in reading the minds of others. That means we are able to successfully predict what other humans perceive, intend, believe, know or desire. Among these abilities, understanding the intention of others is crucial. It allows us to resolve possible ambiguities of physical actions. For example, if you were to see someone breaking a car window, you would probably assume he was trying to steal a stranger’s car. He would need to be judged differently if he had lost his car keys and it was his own car that he was trying to break into.

src: 人間は他人の心を読むという点では、圧倒的に最も優秀な種である。 つまり、自分以外の人間が何を認識し、何を考え、何を信じ、何を知り、何を望んでいるかを予測できるということです。 これらの能力の中でも、他人の意図を理解することは非常に重要です。それにより、起こり得る物理的な行動における曖昧さを解決することができます。 例えば、車の窓を割っている人を見かけたら、他人の車を盗もうとしていると思うことでしょう。 車の鍵を紛失し、自分の車に侵入しようとしている人だとしたら、別の判断をする必要があるでしょう。
mt: Humans are by far the most adept at reading the minds of others, meaning that we can predict what other humans recognize, think, believe, know, and want. Of these abilities, understanding the intentions of others is particularly important, as it allows us to resolve ambiguities in physical actions. For example, if you see someone breaking a car window, you might think they are trying to steal a car. If you see someone trying to break into your car, you might make a different judgment.
ref: Humans are by far the most talented species in reading the minds of others. That means we are able to successfully predict what other humans perceive, intend, believe, know or desire. Among these abilities, understanding the intention of others is crucial. It allows us to resolve possible ambiguities of physical actions. For example, if you were to see someone breaking a car window, you would probably assume he was trying to steal a stranger’s car. He would need to be judged differently if he had lost his car keys and it was his own car that he was trying to break into.

src: AIはSF的な意味合いが強いものの、コンピュータサイエンスにおける非常に重要な分野を形成しており、行動、学習、知的適応を機械で処理します。 AI研究には、知能を必要とする行動が求められるタスクを自動化する機械の製作が関わってきます。 例を挙げると、制御、計画、スケジュール管理、顧客の診断や質問に回答する機能、ならびに手書き文字、音声、顔の認識などがあります。 そういったものは、実生活の問題解決に焦点を当てた別の分野になっています。 現在、AIシステムは家庭用のコンピュータやビデオゲームソフトの一部に組み込まれる一方で、経済、医療、工学、軍事の分野で高い頻度で使用されています。
mt: AI is a field that is often associated with science fiction, but it is also an important field of computer science that processes actions, learning, and intelligent adaptation by machines. AI research involves the creation of machines that automate tasks that require intelligence, such as control, planning, scheduling, customer diagnosis and answering questions, as well as handwriting, voice, and face recognition. These are focused on solving real-life problems in other fields. Currently, AI systems are being integrated into home computers and video game software, while being used at high frequencies in the fields of economics, medicine, engineering, and the military.
ref: Although AI has a strong connotation of science fiction, AI forms a very important branch of computer science, dealing with behavior, learning and intelligent adaptation in a machine. Research in AI involves making machines to automate tasks that require intelligent behavior. Examples include control, planning and scheduling, the ability to answer customer diagnoses and questions, as well as handwriting recognition, voice and face. Such things have become separate disciplines, which focus on providing solutions to real life problems. The AI ​​system is now often used in the fields of economics, medicine, engineering and the military, as has been built in several home computer and video game software applications.

src: 収束思考パターンは、異なる発想や分野をつなげて解決策を見つけようとする問題解決手法です。 このマインドセットの焦点は、スピード、論理性、正確性にあり、事実の特定、既存のテクニックの再適用、情報収集にも力を入れています。 この考え方の最も重要な要素は、「正解は1つしかない」という点です。正しいか間違っているかという2つの答えしか考えないのです。 このような考え方は、特定の科学や標準的な手順に関連付けられています。 この種の人は論理的思考力に富み、パターンを記憶したり、問題を解決したり、科学的なテストに取り組んだりできます。
mt: Convergent thinking patterns are problem-solving techniques that seek to connect different ideas or fields to find solutions. The focus of this mindset is speed, logic, and accuracy, and it involves fact-finding, reapplying existing techniques, and information gathering. The most important element of this way of thinking is that "the answer is one." There are only two answers: right or wrong. This way of thinking is associated with specific sciences or standard procedures. Such people are rich in logical thinking power, can remember patterns, solve problems, and engage in scientific testing.
ref: Convergent thinking patterns are problem solving techniques that unite different ideas or fields to find a solution. The focus of this mindset is speed, logic and accuracy, also identification of facts, reapplying existing techniques, gathering information. The most important factor of this mindset is: there is only one correct answer. You only think of two answers, namely right or wrong. This type of thinking is associated with certain science or standard procedures. People with this type of thinking have logical thinking, are able to memorize patterns, solve problems and work on scientific tests.

src: ビデオ録画の利用は、数ミリ秒程度続く微表情、つまり顔の動きを解釈するうえで重要な発見につながっています。 特に、微表情を正確に解釈することによって、その人が嘘をついているかどうかを見抜けると主張しています。 オリバー・サックス氏は、論文「大統領のスピーチ」の中で、脳に障害があってスピーチを理解できない人でも、誠実さを正しく評価できると指摘しています。 人間行動を解釈するそのような能力は、飼い犬などの動物にも共通しているのではないかとまで彼は示唆しています。
mt: The use of video recordings has led to important discoveries about microexpressions, which are facial movements that last only a few milliseconds. In particular, they claim that by accurately interpreting microexpressions, you can tell if someone is lying. Oliver Sacks points out in his paper "Presidential Speech" that people with brain damage who cannot understand speech can still accurately assess sincerity. He also suggests that such abilities are shared by animals such as dogs.
ref: The use of video recording has led to important discoveries in the interpretation of micro-expressions, facial movements which last a few milliseconds. In particular, it is claimed that one can detect whether a person is lying by interpreting micro-expressions correctly. Oliver Sacks, in his paper The President's Speech, indicated how people who are unable to understand speech because of brain damage are nevertheless able to assess sincerity accurately. He even suggests that such abilities in interpreting human behavior may be shared by animals such as domestic dogs.

src: 上記のように知識を得る能力や学習能力が変化するにつれて知識を得る基準率が変わってきました。 情報を入手するためのアプローチが異なりました。個人の内面に存在するプレッシャーが想起されることはなく、文面を思い出す能力により焦点が当てられるようになっていました。 要するに、ルネサンスは、学習法や知識の普及に大きな変化をもたらしたのです。
mt: As knowledge changes, so does the rate at which knowledge is acquired. The approach to obtaining information has changed. The pressure that exists within the individual is not brought to mind, and the ability to recall the text focuses. In other words, the Renaissance brought about a major change in the way of learning and the spread of knowledge.
ref: As the ability to obtain knowledge and to learn changed in such a way as mentioned above the base rate at which knowledge was obtained changed. The approach to obtaining information was different. No longer did pressure reside within individual recall, but the ability to recall text became more of a focus. In essence, the Renaissance made a significant change in the approach to learning and the dissemination of knowledge.

src: インターネットは、マスコミュニケーションと対人コミュニケーションの両要素を兼ね備えた環境です。 インターネットの顕著な特徴は、利用と満足のアプローチの観点からさらなる次元を導き出します。 例えば、インターネット利用の重要な動機として「学習」や「社会化」が示唆されています(James et al., 1995)。 「個人的関与」と「継続的関係」は、Eighmey & McCord（1998）がウェブサイトに対する視聴者の反応を調査した際に、新たな動機付けの側面として特定されました。
mt: The Internet is an environment that combines mass communication and interpersonal communication. The Internet's most prominent feature is that it leads to further dimensions from the perspective of use and satisfaction. For example, learning and socialization are suggested as important motives for Internet use (James et al., 1995). "Personal involvement" and "continuing relationship" were identified as new motivational aspects when Eighmey & McCord (1998) investigated viewers' responses to websites.
ref: The Internet combines elements of both mass and interpersonal communication. The distinct characteristics of the Internet lead to additional dimensions in terms of the uses and gratifications approach. For example, “learning” and “socialization” are suggested as important motivations for Internet use (James et al., 1995). “Personal involvement” and “continuing relationships” were also identified as new motivation aspects by Eighmey and McCord (1998) when they investigated audience reactions to websites.

src: ゴシック様式の最盛期は10～11世紀にかけてと14世紀でした。 当初の装いは東方のビザンチン文化の影響を強く受けたものでした。 しかし、通信経路が遅いため、西欧のスタイルは25～30年遅れている可能性があります。 中世の終焉に向かって、西ヨーロッパは独自の様式を開発し始めました。十字軍の結果として生じた当時としては最大の進歩の1つは、衣類を閉じるためにボタンを使用し始めたことです。
mt: The Gothic style reached its peak in the 10th and 11th centuries and again in the 14th century. The original dress was strongly influenced by the Byzantine culture of the East. However, because of the slow communication, the Western style may have been 25 to 30 years behind. As the Middle Ages came to an end, Western Europe began to develop its own style. One of the greatest advances of the time, resulting from the Crusades, was the use of buttons to close clothing.
ref: Gothic style peaked in the period between the 10th - 11th centuries and the 14th century. At the beginning dress was heavily influenced by the Byzantine culture in the east. However, due to the slow communication channels, styles in the west could lag behind by 25 to 30 year. towards the end of the Middle Ages western Europe began to develop their own style. one of the biggest developments of the time as a result of the crusades people began to use buttons to fasten clothing.

src: もっと環境に優しい生活を始めてもいいし、環境運動に参加してもいいし、将来の苦しみをある程度軽減するために活動家になってもいいのです。 多くの場合、これは対症療法のようなものです。しかし、一時的な解決を求めるだけではなく、問題の根本原因を突き止め、それを不活性化させる必要があります。 人類の科学技術の進歩によって世界は大きく変わり、過剰な人口と贅沢な生活が原因で問題が拡大したことは十分に明白な事実です。
mt: You can start living a more environmentally friendly life, you can join the environmental movement, you can become an activist to mitigate future suffering. In many cases, this is like symptomatic treatment. However, you need to find the root cause of the problem and deactivate it, not just seek temporary solutions. It is a well-known fact that the world has changed greatly due to the progress of human science and technology, and the problem has expanded due to excessive population and luxurious life.
ref: We can start living more friendly to the environment, we can join to the environmental movement, and we can even be activists in order to reduce the future suffering in some degree. This is just like symptomatic treatment in many cases. However, if we do not only want a temporary solution, then we should find the root of the problems, and we should deactivate them. It is obvious enough that the world has changed much because of humankind's scientific and technological advancements, and problems have become greater because of overpopulation and mankind's extravagant lifestyle.

src: もっと環境に優しい生活を始めてもいいし、環境運動に参加してもいいし、将来の苦しみをある程度軽減するために活動家になってもいいのです。 多くの場合、これは対症療法のようなものです。しかし、一時的な解決を求めるだけではなく、問題の根本原因を突き止め、それを不活性化させる必要があります。 人類の科学技術の進歩によって世界は大きく変わり、過剰な人口と贅沢な生活が原因で問題が拡大したことは十分に明白な事実です。

src: パワーバランスとは、欧州諸国が欧州全域の国家主権を維持しようとする制度でした。 そのコンセプトは、欧州では一国の強大化を防ぐために、どの国の政府もしばしば同盟関係を変えながらバランスを維持するというものでした。 スペイン継承戦争は、欧州のパワーバランスが中心的な問題となって起きた最初の戦争でした。 これは重要な変化を示しています。というのも、ヨーロッパの大国にはもはや宗教戦争という口実がなくなっていったのです。そのため、この三十年戦争は、宗教戦争と呼ばれる最後の戦争となりました。
mt: The Balance of Power was a system in which European countries sought to maintain sovereignty over the entire continent. The concept was that each government would maintain a balance by changing alliances frequently to prevent any one country from becoming too powerful. The Spanish Succession was the first war in which the Balance of Power was a central issue. This is an important change. Because there were no longer religious wars as a pretext for the great powers of Europe, this Thirty Years' War was the last war to be called a religious war.
ref: The balance of power was a system in which European nations sought to maintain the national sovereignty of all European states. The concept was that all European nations had to seek to prevent one nation from becoming powerful, and thus national governments often changed their alliances in order to maintain the balance. The War of Spanish Succession marked the first war whose central issue was the balance of power. This marked an important change, as European powers would no longer have the pretext of being religious wars. Thus, the Thirty Years' War would be the last war to be labeled a religious war.

src: ヨーロッパ史において経済的に豊かで強大な力を持つようになったカトリック教会に、この時代には厳しい目が向けられるようになっていました。 キリスト教は千年以上にわたって言語や習慣の違うヨーロッパの国々を結びつけてきました。 その普遍的な力は、王から平民に至るまで、すべての人に影響を与えていました。 キリスト教の主な教義の1つは、富は苦しみや貧困を軽減する目的に使われるべきであり、教会の基金はそのための特別な存在であるということです。 教会の中央権力は千年以上も前からローマにあり、権力と資金が集中することで、多くの人がその教義が満たされているかどうかを疑問視するようになりました。
mt: The Catholic Church, which had become economically powerful and dominant in Europe, was now under scrutiny. Christianity had been uniting the countries of Europe for over a thousand years, with its universal power affecting everyone from kings to peasants. One of the main tenets of Christianity was that wealth should be used to alleviate suffering and poverty, and that the Church's funds were a special entity for that purpose. The central power of the Church had been in Rome for over a thousand years, and the concentration of power and money led many to question whether the tenets were being fulfilled.
ref: During this period of European history, the Catholic Church, which had become rich and powerful, came under scrutiny. For over a thousand years the Christian religion had bound European states together despite differences in language and customs. I Its all-pervading power affected everyone from king to commoner. One of the main Christian tenets is that wealth should be used to alleviate suffering and poverty and that the monetary funds of the church are there specifically for that reason. The central authority of the church had been in Rome for over a thousand years and this concentration of power and money led many to question whether this tenet was being met.

src: 1789年10月6日、恐怖におびえた国王ルイ16世、王妃マリー・アントワネットと2人の幼い子供たち（11歳のマリー・テレーズと4歳のルイ＝シャルル）、そして国王の妹であるエリザベス王女は、暴徒と化した市場の女性たちによってヴェルサイユ宮殿からパリへと強制的に戻されました。 馬車に乗った彼らは、国王と王妃に向かって叫び、脅しの言葉を浴びせる暴徒に囲まれてパリに戻りました。 暴徒と化した群衆は、王と王妃に馬車の窓を無理やり開けさせました。 あるとき、恐怖に怯える王妃の前で、暴徒の1人がヴェルサイユ宮殿で殺された王室の衛兵の首を振って見せた。
mt: 1789 October 6, the terrified King Louis XVI, Queen Marie Antoinette and her two young children (11-year-old Marie-Thérèse and 4-year-old Louis-Charles), and the king's sister, Princess Elizabeth, were forcibly returned from the palace of Versailles to Paris by rioting women. They rode in a carriage surrounded by rioters who shouted and threatened them. The rioters forced open the windows of the carriage in front of the king and queen. Once, a rioter showed the queen the severed head of a royal guard killed in the palace of Versailles in front of the terrified queen.
ref: The terrified King Louis XVI, Queen Marie Antoinette their two young children (11 year old Marie Therese and four year old Louis-Charles) and the King's sister, Madam Elizabeth, on the 6th October 1789 were forced back to Paris from Versailles by a mob of market women. In a carriage, they traveled back to Paris surrounded by a mob of people screaming and shouting threats against the King and Queen. The mob of people forced the King And Queen to have their carriage windows wide open. At one point a member of the mob waved the head of a royal guard killed at Versailles in front of the terrified Queen.

src: 敵対行為が始まってまもなく、イギリスはドイツに対する海上封鎖を開始しました。 この戦略は効果的であり、重要な軍事物資や民間物資の供給を遮断したが、この封鎖は過去2世紀のいくつもの国際協定によって成文化され一般的に認められた国際法に違反していました。 英国は、船舶が海洋全域に進入するのを防ぐために公海に機雷を仕掛け、中立船にまで危険をもたらしました。 この戦術に対する反応が限られていたため、ドイツはその無制限の水中戦にも同様の反応を想定していました。
mt: The British began a naval blockade of Germany shortly after the hostilities began. This strategy was effective in cutting off the supply of important military and civilian goods, but this blockade violated international law, which had been codified and generally accepted for over two centuries in a number of international agreements. The British laid mines in international waters to prevent ships from entering the ocean, endangering neutral vessels. The Germans had not anticipated a limited response to this tactic, and so they had not anticipated a similar response to their unrestricted submarine warfare.
ref: Soon after the outbreak of hostilities, Britain initiated a naval blockade of Germany. The strategy proved effective, cutting off vital military and civilian supplies, although this blockade violated generally accepted international law codified by several international agreements of the past two centuries. Britain mined international waters to prevent any ships from entering entire sections of ocean, causing danger to even neutral ships. Since there was limited response to this tactic, Germany expected a similar response to its unrestricted submarine warfare.

src: 米国では、多発性硬化症（MS）の既知の症例数が約40万人と言われ、若年者および中年者の代表的な神経疾患として知られています。 MSは、脳、脊髄、視神経からなる中枢神経系に影響を与える病気です。 研究によると、女性が多発性硬化症（MS）を発症する確率は男性の倍であることがわかっています。
mt: 40,000 people in the United States are known to have multiple sclerosis (MS), a common neurological disease of young and middle-aged adults. MS affects the central nervous system, which includes the brain, spinal cord, and optic nerve. Research shows that women are twice as likely as men to develop MS.
ref: Across the United States of America, there are approximately 400,000 known cases of Multiple Sclerosis (MS), leaving it as the leading neurological disease in younger and middle aged adults. MS is a disease that affects the central nervous system, which is made up of the brain, the spinal cord and the optic nerve. Research has found that females are two times more likely to have MS then males.

src: この研究では、腰痛患者の痛みと障害の関係には、抑うつ、恐怖、破局化が介在していることがわかりました。 うつ病や恐怖ではなく、破局化の効果のみが、週例の構造化PAセッションの条件となっていました。 定期的な活動に参加している人は、慢性疼痛と正常な身体運動から生まれる不快感との違いを区別する痛みの否定的知覚については、より多くの支援が必要でした。
mt: This study found that depression, fear, and disengagement were involved in the relationship between pain and disability in patients with low back pain.  The effects of depression and fear were not present, but disengagement was present in the condition of weekly structured PA sessions.  People who participated in regular activities needed more support in distinguishing pain from discomfort from normal physical activity.
ref: The study found that depression, fear and catastrophising mediated the relationship between pain and disability in lower back pain sufferers. Only the effects of catastrophizing, not depression and fear was conditional of regular weekly structured PA sessions. Those participating in regular activity required more support in terms of negative perception of pain distinguishing the differences of chronic pain and discomfort feel from normal physical movement.

src: 近代スポーツのフェンシングは、大学生からプロやオリンピック競技まで、さまざまなレベルで行われています。 このスポーツは2人の選手が向かい合って対戦し、両者が剣で攻防を繰り広げます。
mt: Modern sports fencing is practiced at various levels, from college students to professionals and Olympic athletes. This sport involves two players facing each other and engaging in combat with swords.
ref: The modern sport of fencing is played at many levels, from students learning at a university to professional and Olympic competition. The sport is primarily played in a duel format, one fencer dueling another.

src: 内部中毒はすぐに明らかにならないことがあります。嘔吐などは一般的な症状であるため、直ちに診断を下すことはできません。 内部中毒の最も明らかな兆候は、薬剤や毒性のある家庭用化学薬品の容器が開いていることです。 毒物のラベルを見て、その特定の毒物に関する応急処置の指示があるかどうかを確認してください。
mt: Internal poisoning may not be immediately apparent. Vomiting is a common symptom, so it is not possible to immediately diagnose internal poisoning. The most obvious sign of internal poisoning is the presence of containers of pharmaceuticals or household chemicals with toxic properties. Check the label of the poison and see if there are instructions for emergency treatment of that specific poison.
ref: Internal poisoning may not be immediately apparent. Symptoms, such as vomiting are sufficiently general that an immediate diagnosis cannot be made. The best indication of internal poisoning may be the presence of an open container of medication or toxic household chemicals. Check the label for specific first aid instructions for that specific poison.

src: 被害者を保護するには、まず現場を調査して安全を確保しなければなりません。 被害者に近づきながら被害者の位置と無意識の危険信号を察知する必要があります。 助けようとして怪我をしたら、事態を悪化させるだけです。
mt: 1. First, you must assess the scene and ensure your safety. 2. Approach the victim while assessing the victim's position and unconscious danger signals. 3. Do not help and get hurt, you will only make things worse.
ref: To Check the victim, you must first survey the scene to ensure your safety. You need to notice the victim's position as you approach him or her and any automatic red flags. If you get hurt trying to help, you may only serve to make matters worse.

src: 被害者を保護するには、まず現場を調査して安全を確保しなければなりません。 被害者に近づきながら被害者の位置と無意識の危険信号を察知する必要があります。 助けようとして怪我をしたら、事態を悪化させるだけです。
mt: 1. First, you must assess the scene and ensure your safety. 2. Approach the victim while assessing the victim's position and unconscious danger signals. 3. Do not help and get hurt, you will only make things worse.
ref: To Check the victim, you must first survey the scene to ensure your safety. You need to notice the victim's position as you approach him or her and any automatic red flags. If you get hurt trying to help, you may only serve to make matters worse.

src: メートル法の採用、絶対主義から共和主義への移行、愛国心、そして国は単独支配者ではなく国民のものであるという信念など、多くの社会的政治的影響がありました。 革命後は職業も公募制になって男性全員に応募資格があり、最も意欲があって勝ち抜いた者が職に就けるようになりました。 軍隊でも同じことが言えます。なぜならば、軍隊の階級に基づいた階級ではなく、能力に基づいた階級になったからです。 フランス革命は、他国にいて抑圧されている多くの労働者階級に刺激を与え、各国で革命が始まりました。
mt: The adoption of the metric system, the transition from absolutism to republicanism, patriotism, and the belief that the nation is not governed by a single ruler but by the people, were among the many social and political influences. After the revolution, the job was also open to all men and the most enthusiastic and successful applicant was hired. The same can be said of the military. Because the military ranks were not based on rank, but on ability. The French Revolution inspired many workers in other countries who were oppressed, and revolutions began in other countries.
ref: There are a lot of social and political effects such as the use of metric system, a shift from absolutism to republicanism, nationalism and the belief the country belongs to the people not to one sole ruler. Also after the Revolution occupations were open to all male applicants allowing the most ambitious and successful to succeed. Same goes for the military because instead of army rankings being based on class they were now based on cailaber. The French Revolution also inspired many other repressed working class people of other country's to began their own revolutions.

src: 社会生活を営む人は誰でも交通機関を利用します。そのほとんど全員が交通システムに不満を抱いています。 先進国では、水質や橋の倒壊などの苦情はほとんど聞きません。 なぜ、交通機関はこのような苦情を生み、日常的に故障するのでしょうか。交通機関の技術者が無能なだけなのでしょうか。それとももっと根本的な問題があるのでしょうか。
mt: Everyone who lives in a society uses transportation. Most of them are dissatisfied with the transportation system. In advanced countries, complaints about water quality and bridge collapses are rare. Why does the transportation system create such complaints and break down so often? Is it because the transportation engineers are incompetent? Or is there a more fundamental problem?
ref: Everyone participates in society and uses transportation systems. Almost everyone complains about transportation systems. In developed countries you seldom hear similar levels of complaints about water quality or bridges falling down. Why do transportation systems engender such complaints, why do they fail on a daily basis? Are transportation engineers just incompetent? Or is something more fundamental going on?

src: 交通流研究とは、2点間にいる個々の運転手と車両の動きとそれらの相互作用の研究です。 残念ながら、運転手の行動を100%の確率で予測することはできないので、交通の流れを研究することは困難です。 幸いなことに、運転手は合理的に一貫性のある範囲内で行動する傾向があり、したがって、交通の流れはある程度の合理的な一貫性を持つ傾向があり、数学的に大まかに表すことができます。 交通流をより適切に表すために、(1) 流れ、(2) 密度、(3) 速度という3つの主要特性の間に関係性が確立されています。 これらの関係は、道路施設の計画、設計、運営に役立ちます。
mt: Traffic flow research is the study of the movement of individual drivers and vehicles and their interactions. Unfortunately, it is not possible to predict the actions of drivers with 100% certainty, so it is difficult to study traffic flow. Fortunately, drivers tend to act in a rational and consistent manner, so that traffic flow tends to have a certain degree of rational and consistent mathematical description. To better describe traffic flow, (1) flow, (2) density, and (3) speed are three major characteristics that are related. These relationships are useful in planning, designing, and operating road facilities.
ref: Traffic Flow is the study of the movement of individual drivers and vehicles between two points and the interactions they make with one another. Unfortunately, studying traffic flow is difficult because driver behavior cannot be predicted with one-hundred percent certainty. Fortunately, drivers tend to behave within a reasonably consistent range; thus, traffic streams tend to have some reasonable consistency and can be roughly represented mathematically. To better represent traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) flow, (2) density, and (3) velocity. These relationships help in planning, design, and operations of roadway facilities.

src: ハーシーとチェイスの実験は、DNAが遺伝物質であることを示唆する有力な実験の1つでした。 ハーシーとチェイスはファージ（ウイルス）を使い、そのDNAをバクテリアに移植しました。 彼らは2つの実験を試み、1つはファージのDNAに放射性のリンで印をつける実験、もう1つはファージのタンパク質に放射性の硫黄で印をつける実験でした。
mt: The Hershey and Chase experiments were one of the most important experiments suggesting that DNA is the genetic material. They used a virus to transplant its DNA into bacteria. They performed two experiments, one to mark the DNA of the virus with radioactive phosphorus, and the other to mark the proteins of the virus with radioactive sulfur.
ref: The Hershey and Chase experiment was one of the leading suggestions that DNA was a genetic material. Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium. They did two experiments marking either the DNA in the phage with a radioactive phosphorus or the protein of the phage with radioactive sulfur.

src: 突然変異は、変異の種類、影響を受けた遺伝物質の欠片の意義、影響を受けた細胞が生殖細胞であるかどうかによって、さまざまな異なる影響を生む可能性があります。 生殖細胞に生じた突然変異だけは子に受け継がれ、他の部位に生じた突然変異は細胞死や癌の原因になる可能性があります。
mt: Mutations can have a variety of different effects depending on the type of mutation, the significance of the piece of genetic material affected, and whether the affected cell is a reproductive cell. Mutations in reproductive cells can be passed on to offspring, while mutations in other cells can cause cell death or cancer.
ref: Mutations can have a variety of different effects depending on the type of mutation, the significance of the piece of genetic material affected and whether the cells affected are germ-line cells. Only mutations in germ-line cells can be passed on to children, while mutations elsewhere can cause cell-death or cancer.

src: ヤギの家畜化は、約1万年前に始まり、その中心はイランのザグロス山脈西部であったとされています。 古代の文化や部族は、乳、毛、肉、皮を簡手に入れやすいヤギを飼い始めました。 一般的に家畜のヤギは、丘陵地やその他の放牧地で放し飼いにされていましたが、ヤギの群れを世話をするヤギ飼いはたいてい少年でした。この習慣は今日でも続いています。
mt: The domestication of goats began about 10,000 years ago, and its center was in the western Zagros Mountains of Iran. Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep goats for their milk, hair, meat, and skins. Goats were generally kept on hillside or other pasture land, but the herders who took care of goat herds were usually boys. This tradition continues today.
ref: Goats seem to have been first domesticated roughly 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains of Iran. Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep them for easy access to milk, hair, meat, and skins. Domestic goats were generally kept in herds that wandered on hills or other grazing areas, often tended by goatherds who were frequently children or adolescents, similar to the more widely known shepherd. These methods of herding are still used today.

src: ゴルフとは、クラブで打ってボールを穴に入れるゲームです。 通常のラウンドでは18ホールを回り、選手は原則としてコースの第1ホールから開始し、第18ホールで終了します。 最少の打数またはクラブのスイング数でコースを終えた選手が勝利します。 このゲームは芝生の上で行われ、ホールの周りの芝生は短く刈られてグリーンと呼ばれています。
mt: Golf is a game in which a player hits a ball with a club into a hole. In a typical round, a player plays 18 holes, and the player starts at the first hole and ends at the eighteenth hole. The player who completes the course in the fewest strokes or swings of the club wins. This game is played on grass, and the grass around the holes is cut short and is called the green.
ref: Golf is a game in which players use clubs to hit balls into holes. Eighteen holes are played during a regular round, with players usually starting on the first hole on the course and finishing on the eighteenth. The player who takes the fewest strokes, or swings of the club, to complete the course wins. The game is played on grass, and the grass around the hole is mown shorter and called the green.

src: 科学の主な目的は、科学的方法によって世界の仕組みを解明することです。実際、この方法はほとんどの科学研究の指針となっています。 しかし、それだけではありません。実験とは、可能性のある仮説の1つ以上を排除するために使用される試験のことで、質問をしたり観察をしたりすることも科学研究の指針となります。
mt: The main purpose of science is to understand the workings of the world through scientific methods. In fact, this method is the guiding principle for most scientific research. But that's not all. An experiment is a test used to eliminate one or more possible hypotheses, and asking questions or observing are also guiding principles of scientific research.
ref: Science’s main goal is to figure out the way the world works through the scientific method. This method in fact guides most scientific research. It isn’t alone though, experimentation, and an experiment is a test that is used to eliminate one or more of the possible hypotheses, asking questions, and making observations also guide scientific research.

src: 竜巻は、他の暴風雨に比べて狭い範囲に発生しますが、その通り道にあるものすべてを破壊する場合があります。 竜巻は木を根こそぎ倒し、建物から屋根や壁板をはぎ取り、車を空に巻き上げます。最も猛威を振るう竜巻の2%は3時間以上続きます。 これらのモンスターストームは、最大風速が時速480km（133m/秒、時速300m）になります。
mt: Tornadoes are rare compared to other storms, but they can destroy everything in their path. Tornadoes rip trees out of the ground, tear roofs and walls off of buildings, and lift cars into the air. The most violent tornadoes can last for more than three hours. These monster storms can reach wind speeds of 480 km/h (133 m/s, 300 mph).
ref: Tornadoes strike a small area compared to other violent storms, but they can destroy everything in their path. Tornadoes uproot trees, rip boards from buildings, and fling cars up into the sky. The most violent two percent of tornadoes last more than three hours. These monster storms have winds up to 480 km/h (133 m/s; 300 mph).

src: 人類は何千年も何千年も前から、拡大用のレンズを作り、使ってきました。 しかし、実用に耐える最初の望遠鏡が作られたのは16世紀後半のヨーロッパでした。 これらの望遠鏡は、2つのレンズを組み合わせたもので、遠方にある物体を近くにあるように拡大して見せる働きをします。
mt: Humans have been making and using magnifying lenses for thousands of years. The first practical telescope was made in 16th century Europe. These telescopes were made by combining two lenses, which work by making distant objects appear closer.
ref: Humans have been making and using lenses for magnification for thousands and thousands of years. However, the first true telescopes were made in Europe in the late 16th century. These telescopes used a combination of two lenses to make distant objects appear both nearer and larger.

src: 人類は何千年も何千年も前から、拡大用のレンズを作り、使ってきました。 しかし、実用に耐える最初の望遠鏡が作られたのは16世紀後半のヨーロッパでした。 これらの望遠鏡は、2つのレンズを組み合わせたもので、遠方にある物体を近くにあるように拡大して見せる働きをします。

ref: Humans have been making and using lenses for magnification for thousands and thousands of years. However, the first true telescopes were made in Europe in the late 16th century. These telescopes used a combination of two lenses to make distant objects appear both nearer and larger.

src: ムハンマドは、日常生活を超えた問題に深い関心を持っていました。彼は、瞑想のために「ヌール」（光）の山にある「ヒーラ」と呼ばれる洞窟をよく訪れました。 時代を超えて残った洞窟は、ムハンマドの精神的な傾倒の様子を鮮明に映し出しています。 洞窟はメッカの北にあたる山頂にあり、外界から完全に隔離されています。 実際には、洞窟の存在を知っていても見つけるのは容易ではありません。洞窟に入ると、そこは完全に隔離された空間です。 上空の澄んだ美しい空と、周囲の多くの山々以外には何も見えません。洞窟の中からは、外界はほとんど見えず、外界の音も聞こえません。
mt: Muhammad was deeply interested in issues that transcended daily life. He often visited a cave called "Hira" on a mountain called "Nur" (light) for meditation. The cave that has survived through the ages vividly depicts Muhammad's spiritual inclination. The cave is on the top of a mountain north of Mecca, completely isolated from the outside world. In fact, even if you know the cave exists, it is not easy to find it. Once you enter the cave, it is completely isolated. Except for the clear, beautiful sky above and the many mountains around, nothing else is visible. From inside the cave, the outside world is hardly visible, and the sounds of the outside world are not heard.
ref: Muhammad was deeply interested in matters beyond this mundane life. He used to frequent a cave that became known as “Hira‘” on the Mountain of “Noor” (light) for contemplation. he cave itself, which survived the times, gives a very vivid image of Muhammad’s spiritual inclinations. Resting on the top of one of the mountains north of Mecca, the cave is completely isolated from the rest of the world. In fact, it is not easy to find at all even if one knew it existed. Once inside the cave, it is a total isolation. Nothing can be seen other than the clear, beautiful sky above and the many surrounding mountains. Very little of this world can be seen or heard from inside the cave.

src: イギリスでは、16世紀にはすでに貨車道が敷設されていました。 貨車道は板材を並行に並べて敷いただけのものでしたが、馬がそれを引くことで、当時のやや荒れた道路よりも大きな荷物を高速に輸送できました。 枕木は、線路を所定の位置に固定するためにかなり早い段階で導入されました。やがて、上部に鉄製の先端部を設けると効率がよいことが徐々にわかってきました。 これが一般的になりましたが、鉄は馬車の木製車輪の摩耗が進む原因になりました。 最終的に、木製の車輪は鉄製の車輪に取って代わられました。1767年、総鉄製レールが初めて導入されました。
mt: 16th century England already had wagonways. Wagonways were simply planks laid parallel to each other, and horses could pull larger loads faster than on the slightly rough roads of the time. Sleepers were introduced to fix the track in the correct position at a fairly early stage. It was gradually realized that having a metal tip on top was more efficient. This became common, but iron caused wear on the wooden wheels of the horse-drawn carriages. Eventually, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first all-iron rail was introduced.
ref: Wagonways were built in England as early as the 16th Century. Although wagonways merely consisted of parallel planks of wood, they allowed horses pulling them to achieve greater speeds and pull larger loads than on the slightly more rough roads of the day. Crossties were introduced fairly early to hold the tracks in place. Gradually, however, it was realised that tracks would be more efficient if they had a stip of iron on the top. This became common practice, but the iron caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons. Eventually, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first full-iron rails were introduced.

src: ロマン主義には、ゲーテ、フィヒテ、シュレーゲルらの作家たちが形成した文化決定論という大要素が存在したのです。 ロマン主義の文脈では、地理が個人を形成し、時間の経過とともにその地理に関わる風習や文化が生まれ、それは社会の場と調和し、勝手に押し付けられた法律よりも優れたものでした。
mt: 1. The Romantics had a strong element of cultural determinism, in which writers such as Goethe, Fichte, and Schlegel believed that geography formed individuals, and that customs and culture that arose with the passage of time and geography were better than laws imposed by society.
ref: Romanticism had a large element of cultural determinism, drawn from writers such as Goethe, Fichte, and Schlegel. In the context of Romanticism, the geography molded individuals, and over time customs and culture related to that geography arose, and these, being in harmony with the place of the society, were better than arbitrarily imposed laws.

src: 技術決定論とは、技術推進や技術的規範から始まり、人間の運命は、科学的な法則と技術におけるその顕在化に関連した根底にある論理によって動かされているという厳密な意味まで、実際には幅広い考え方を包含する用語です。 技術決定論のほとんどの解釈は、2つの一般論を共有しています。1つは技術の発展自体が文化的・政治的な影響を大きく超えた道をたどっていること、もう1つは技術が社会的に条件づけられたものではなく、むしろ内在する社会に「影響」を与えることです。 例えば、自動車は必然的に道路の発達につながると言えるかもしれません。 しかし、ほんの一握りの車だけでは全国的な道路網の採算が合わないので、車の所有コストを下げるために新しい生産方法が開発さけています。 自動車の保有者増加は、道路事故発生率の増加につながり、結果として、負傷した身体を治療するための新技術が医療分野で開発されることになります。
mt: Technological determinism is a broad term that encompasses a wide range of ideas, from the idea that technological progress is driven by the advancement of science and technology, to the idea that human destiny is determined by the laws of science and the manifestation of technology. Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general ideas. One is that the development of technology itself has gone beyond cultural and political influences. The other is that technology is not socially conditioned, but rather that it conditions the society in which it is embedded. For example, it can be said that cars lead to the development of roads. However, a few cars alone would not be profitable for a national road network, so new production methods are developed to lower the cost of owning a car. The increase in car ownership leads to an increase in road accidents, which in turn leads to the development of new technologies for treating injured bodies in the medical field.
ref: "Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from technology-push or the technological imperative to a strict sense that human destiny is driven by an underlying logic associated with scientific laws and their manifestation in technology. Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general ideas: that the development of technology itself follows a path largely beyond cultural or political influence, and that technology in turn has ""effects"" on societies that are inherent, rather than socially conditioned. For example, one might say that the motor car necessarily leads to the development of roads. However, a nationwide road network is not economically viable for just a handful of cars, so new methods of production are developed to reduce the cost of car ownership. Mass car ownership also leads to a higher incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in healthcare for repairing damaged bodies."

src: 上げ弓のマークはV字のように見え、下げ弓のマークはホチキスの針または四角形の底辺が欠けたような形です。 アップとは先端から始めて弓を押すことであり、ダウンはフロッグ（手で弓を保持している場所）から始めて弓を引くことです。 上げ弓は通常やわらかい音を、下げ弓はより強く、主張のある音を生み出します。 鉛筆で自由に符号を書き込めますが、印字された弓形の符合には音楽的な理由があることを覚えておきましょう。通常、その符号に従うべきです。
mt: The up bow mark looks like a V, and the down bow mark looks like a safety pin or a square with one corner missing. Up bows are played by pushing the bow from the tip, and down bows are played by pulling the bow from the frog. Up bows usually produce a soft sound, and down bows produce a stronger, more assertive sound. You can write your own bow marks with a pencil, but remember that there is a musical reason for the printed bow marks. You should usually follow them.
ref: "The ""up bow"" mark looks like a V and the ""down bow mark"" like a staple or a square missing its bottom side. Up means you should start at the tip and push the bow, and down means you should start at the frog (which is where your hand is holding the bow) and pull the bow. An up-bow usually generates a softer sound, while a down-bow is stronger and more assertive. Feel free to pencil in your own marks, but remember the printed bowing marks are there for a musical reason, so they should usually be respected."

src: 上げ弓のマークはV字のように見え、下げ弓のマークはホチキスの針または四角形の底辺が欠けたような形です。 アップとは先端から始めて弓を押すことであり、ダウンはフロッグ（手で弓を保持している場所）から始めて弓を引くことです。 上げ弓は通常やわらかい音を、下げ弓はより強く、主張のある音を生み出します。 鉛筆で自由に符号を書き込めますが、印字された弓形の符合には音楽的な理由があることを覚えておきましょう。通常、その符号に従うべきです。

src: 他の霊長類とは異なり、ヒト科の動物は、移動したり、体重を支えたり、木々の間を通り抜ける際に手を使用しなくなっています。 チンパンジーの手足の大きさと長さはほぼ同じであり、ナックル歩行をする際に体重を支えるために手を使っていることが示されています。 人間の手（中指先から手首まで）は足（つま先から踵まで）よりも短く、指骨はまっすぐです。 200～300万年前の化石の手の骨から、このように手が運動から操作へと特化していたことがわかります。
mt: Unlike other primates, members of the genus Homo use their hands for locomotion, weight-bearing, and passing through trees. The hands of chimpanzees are nearly the same size and length as their feet, and they use their hands to support their weight when walking on knuckles. The human hand (from the knuckle to the wrist) is shorter than the foot (from the toe to the ankle), and the phalanges are straight. This can be seen in the fossilized bones of hands from 200 to 300 million years ago, showing that the hands had specialized from motion to manipulation.
ref: Unlike other primates, hominids no longer use their hands in locomotion or bearing weight or swinging through the trees. The chimpanzee's hand and foot are similar in size and length, reflecting the hand's use for bearing weight in knuckle walking. The human hand is shorter than the foot, with straighter phalanges. Fossil hand bones two million to three million years old reveal this shift in specialization of the hand from locomotion to manipulation.

src: 20世紀の研究では、遺伝的変異には隠れたものと発現したものの2つの遺伝子プールがあることがわかっています。 突然変異で新しい遺伝的変異が加わり、淘汰によってそれが発現された変異のプールから取り除かれます。 棲み分けと組み換えは、世代ごとに2つのプールの間を行き来しながら変異をシャッフルします。
mt: 20th century research showed that genetic variation is divided into two pools of expressed and hidden genes. Mutations add new genetic variation to the expressed pool, and natural selection removes the expressed variation from the pool. Assortative mating and recombination shuffle variation between the two pools across generations.
ref: Twentieth century research has shown that there are two pools of genetic variation: hidden and expressed. Mutation adds new genetic variation, and selection removes it from the pool of expressed variation. Segregation and recombination shuffle variation back and forth between the two pools with each generation.

src: 20世紀の研究では、遺伝的変異には隠れたものと発現したものの2つの遺伝子プールがあることがわかっています。 突然変異で新しい遺伝的変異が加わり、淘汰によってそれが発現された変異のプールから取り除かれます。 棲み分けと組み換えは、世代ごとに2つのプールの間を行き来しながら変異をシャッフルします。

Mutations add new genetic variation to the expressed pool, and natural selection removes the expressed variation from the pool. Assortative mating and recombination shuffle variation between the two pools across generations.
ref: Twentieth century research has shown that there are two pools of genetic variation: hidden and expressed. Mutation adds new genetic variation, and selection removes it from the pool of expressed variation. Segregation and recombination shuffle variation back and forth between the two pools with each generation.

src: 人間のような消化器系を持つ霊長類にとって、サバンナの環境で手に入る植物資源から必須アミノ酸を摂取するのは困難です。 しかも、それを怠ると、成長抑制、栄養失調など深刻な事態につながり、最終的には死を招きます。 最も入手しやすい植物資源は、葉や豆類に含まれるタンパク質でしたが、これは私たちのような霊長類にとって調理しないと消化しにくい栄養素です。 一方、動物性食物（アリ、シロアリ、卵）は消化しやすいうえに、必須アミノ酸をすべて含む良質なタンパク質源です。 あらゆる点を考え合わせれば、私たちの祖先が今日のサバンナに生息するチンパンジーと同じように「タンパク質の問題」を解決していたとしても不思議はありません。
mt: For primates with a digestive system like ours, it is difficult to obtain the essential amino acids from the plant resources available in the savanna environment. And if you neglect this, it can lead to serious consequences such as growth inhibition, malnutrition, and ultimately death. The most easily available plant resources were proteins in leaves and legumes, but these are difficult to digest for us primates unless they are cooked. On the other hand, animal food (ants, termites, eggs) is easy to digest and contains high-quality proteins that contain all the essential amino acids. It is not surprising that our ancestors solved the "protein problem" in the same way as today's chimpanzees living in the savanna, even if you put all the points together.
ref: "Out on the savanna, it is hard for a primate with a digestive system like that of humans to satisfy its amino-acid requirements from available plant resources. Moreover, failure to do so has serious consequences: growth depression, malnutrition, and ultimately death. The most readily accessible plant resources would have been the proteins accessible in leaves and legumes, but these are hard for primates like us to digest unless they are cooked. In contrast, animal foods (ants, termites, eggs) not only are easily digestible, but they provide high-quantity proteins that contain all the essential amino acids. All things considered, we should not be surprised if our own ancestors solved their ""protein problem"" in somewhat the same way that chimps on the savanna do today."

src: サブカルチャーは、社会の基準から外れて軽視されていると感じている同好の士が集まって、自分らしさを養えるようにする文化です。 サブカルチャーの特徴は、所属するメンバーの年齢、民族、階級、場所、性別などによって決まることがあります。 サブカルチャーの特徴を決定付ける性質は、言語、美、宗教、政治、性、地理、またはそれらの要素の組み合わせかもしれません。 サブカルチャーのメンバーはしばしば、ファッション、マンネリズム、隠語を含む象徴的な独特のスタイルで、自分がその一員であることを示します。
mt: Subculture is a culture that people who feel marginalized by the standards of society gather to nurture their individuality. Characteristics of subculture can be determined by age, ethnicity, class, location, gender, etc. of its members. Characteristics of subculture can be determined by language, beauty, religion, politics, sex, geography, or combinations of these elements. Members of subculture often show their membership by a distinctive style that includes fashion, cliché, and symbolic jargon.
ref: Subcultures bring together like-minded individuals who feel neglected by societal standards and allow them to develop a sense of identity. Subcultures can be distinctive because of the age, ethnicity, class, location, and/or gender of the members. The qualities that determine a subculture as distinct may be linguistic, aesthetic, religious, political, sexual, geographical, or a combination of factors. Members of a subculture often signal their membership through a distinctive and symbolic use of style, which includes fashions, mannerisms, and argot.

src: 子供たちはごく幼少期から人種や人種の固定観念に対する意識が発達し、こうした人種の固定観念が行動に影響を与えます。 例えば、学校でうまくいかないと既成概念にはまっている少数派の人種と自分を重ね合わせる子供は、自分の人種に関わる既成概念を知ると、学校でうまくいかなくなる傾向があります。
mt: Children develop racial and ethnic stereotypes at a very young age, and these stereotypes can influence their behavior. For example, children who are members of a minority group and who are not doing well in school may associate themselves with negative stereotypes about their own racial or ethnic group when they learn about these stereotypes, and they may be more likely to do poorly in school.
ref: Children develop an awareness of race and racial stereotypes quite young and these racial stereotypes affect behavior. For instance, children who identify with a racial minority that is stereotyped as not doing well in school tend to not do well in school once they learn about the stereotype associated with their race.

src: 社会化の重要性を示すために用いられる最も一般的な方法の1つは、育児放棄、不運、または故意の虐待によって、成長過程で大人によって社会への適応が阻まれた子供たちの数少ない不幸な事例を取りあげることです。 このような子供は「野生児」または「フェラルキッド」と呼ばれます。野生児は人（通常は自分の親）に監禁されている場合もあり、このような育児放棄の原因としては、重度の知的・身体的障害を持つ子供の育児を親が拒否した場合もあります。 野生児は、捨てられたり、逃げ出したりする前に、重度の児童虐待やトラウマを経験している可能性があります。 また、動物に育てられたとされる者もいれば、野生状態で自力で生きていたとされる者もいます。 人間以外の動物に育てられて成長した野生児は、人間を恐れたり、人間に無関心であるなど、その動物とほとんど同じような行動を（物理的な範囲内）を示します。
mt: One of the most common ways to demonstrate the importance of socialization is to cite the unfortunate cases of children who, due to neglect, misfortune, or intentional abuse, were prevented from adapting to society during their growth process. Such children are called "wild children" or "feral kids." Wild children may be confined by people (usually their parents), and such neglect may be due to parents refusing to care for children with severe mental or physical disabilities. Wild children may have experienced severe child abuse or trauma before being abandoned or running away. There are also those who were raised by animals, and those who survived in the wild on their own. Wild children raised by non-human animals exhibit similar behaviors (within physical range) to the animal they were raised by, such as being afraid of or uninterested in humans.
ref: "One of the most common methods used to illustrate the importance of socialization is to draw upon the few unfortunate cases of children who were, through neglect, misfortune, or wilful abuse, not socialized by adults while they were growing up. Such children are called ""feral"" or wild. Some feral children have been confined by people (usually their own parents); in some cases this child abandonment was due to the parents' rejection of a child's severe intellectual or physical impairment. Feral children may have experienced severe child abuse or trauma before being abandoned or running away. Others are alleged to have been brought up by animals; some are said to have lived in the wild on their own. When completely brought up by non-human animals, the feral child exhibits behaviors (within physical limits) almost entirely like those of the particular care-animal, such as its fear of or indifference to humans."

src: 自給自足農業とは、農業従事者とその家族に必要な分の食料のみを生産する農業の形態です。 自給自足農業とは、生態系地域に自生している保存された種子を、輪作やその他の比較的単純な技術と組み合わせて収量の最大化を図るシンプルなシステムで、多くの場合は有機的な農業です。 歴史的には農家の大半が自給自足農業を営んでおり、発展途上国の多くでは今もその傾向が見られます。
mt: Self-sufficient agriculture is a form of agriculture in which farmers and their families produce only the amount of food necessary for themselves. Self-sufficient agriculture is a simple system that combines native seeds that grow naturally in the ecosystem with crop rotation and other relatively simple techniques to maximize yield, and is often organic. Historically, most farmers have practiced self-sufficient agriculture, and this trend is still seen in many developing countries.
ref: Subsistence agriculture is agriculture carried out for the production of enough food to meet just the needs of the agriculturalist and his/her family. Subsistence agriculture is a simple, often organic, system using saved seed native to the ecoregion combined with crop rotation or other relatively simple techniques to maximize yield. Historically most farmers were engaged in subsistence agriculture and this is still the case in many developing nations.

src: おそらく、最も一般的な観光事業の形態は、ほとんどの人が旅行と関連付ける観光レクリエーションです。 これは、人々が日常生活とはまったく違う場所に行き、ゆったりした気分で楽しんでいる時です。 ビーチ、テーマパーク、キャンプ場は、観光レクリエーション客がよく訪れる最も一般的な場所です。 特定の場所を訪れる目的がその場所の歴史や文化を知ることである場合、その種の観光は文化観光と呼ばれます。 観光客は、1国のさまざまなランドマークを訪れることも、1つの地域のみに集中するという選択肢もあります。
mt: The most common form of tourism is recreational tourism, which most people associate with travel. This is when people go to a place that is completely different from their daily lives and enjoy themselves in a relaxed manner. Beaches, theme parks, and campgrounds are the most common places visited by recreational tourists. When the purpose of visiting a specific place is to learn about the history or culture of that place, this type of tourism is called cultural tourism. Tourists can choose to visit the landmarks of one country or to focus on one region.
ref: Perhaps the most common type of tourism is what most people associate with traveling: Recreation tourism. This is when people go to a place that is very different from their regular day-to-day life to relax and have fun. Beaches, theme parks and camp grounds are often the most common places frequented by recreational tourists. If the objective of one’s visit to a particular place is to get to know its history and culture then this type of tourism is known as cultural tourism. Tourists may visit different landmarks of a particular country or they may simply opt to focus on just one area.
