src: 数十年前から関わってきた個人の方々が、困難や失敗を率直に評価しながらも、私たちの強みや情熱を評価するのを手伝ってくれました。 個人、家族、組織の話を聞く中で、過去の歴史や組織の文化に善悪の影響を与えた人物について、貴重な洞察を得ることができました。 自分史を理解しているからといって文化を理解していることにはなりませんが、少なくとも組織の歴史の範囲内で自分が置かれた立場を理解するのに役立ちます。 成功を評価し、失敗を自覚する中で、個人や参加者全体が、組織の価値観や使命、原動力などをより深く発見していきます。 この例では、過去の起業家としての行動とその結果としての成功例を思い出すことで、地域教会の新しい変化や新しい方向性を人々が受け入れるようになりました。 このような成功例は、将来の変化への恐怖心を軽減しながら、変化に向けて前向きな傾向を生み出します。
mt: People who have been involved for decades have helped us evaluate our strengths and passions while being honest about the difficulties and failures.  Listening to individuals, families, and organizations has given us valuable insights into the people who have influenced the good and bad of the past history and culture of the organization.  Just because you understand your own history does not mean you understand the culture, but at least it helps you understand the position you are in within the organization.  Evaluating successes and failures helps individuals and participants discover the values, mission, and driving forces of the organization more deeply.  In this case, recalling past entrepreneurial actions and the successes that resulted helped people accept the new changes and new directions of the local church.  Such success stories help reduce the fear of future changes while creating a positive trend toward change.
ref: Individuals who had been involved for several decades helped us appreciate our strengths and passions while candidly assessing difficulties and even failures. While listening to individuals share their individual, family, and organizational stories, we gained valuable insight into the past and some of the personalities who influenced for good or ill the culture of the organization. While understanding one’s history does not assume understanding of culture, it does at least help people gain a sense of where they fall within the history of the organization. While assessing the successes and becoming aware of failures, individuals and the whole of the participating persons discover more deeply the values, mission, and driving forces of the organization. In this instance, recalling previous instances of entrepreneurial behavior and resulting successes helped people to be open to new changes and new direction for the local church. Such success stories lessened the fears of change, while creating positive inclinations toward change in the future.

src: ポストモダンの学習方法は、絶対的な考え方から解放されています。優れた学習方法は1つではありません。 実際、学ぶべきことは1つとは限りません。学習とは、学習者と提示された知識の間で経験というかたちで発生するものです。 日曜大工と情報提示、学習ベースのテレビ番組すべてからこれまでに得た私たちの経験がこの点を物語っています。 ですから、私たちの多くは、テレビ番組で放映されるプロセスや経験に私たちが参加したり知識を応用したりはできないことに気づくわけです。 車を点検整備したり、裏庭に噴水を作ったり、ペルーに旅行して古代遺跡を調査したり、隣人の家を改造したりすることは絶対にありません。
mt: Postmodern learning methods are freed from absolute thinking. There is no one great way to learn. In fact, there is no one thing to learn. Learning is an experience that happens between the learner and the knowledge presented. Our experiences with carpentry and information presentation, and learning-based television programs tell us this. So, we realize that we cannot participate in or apply knowledge to the processes or experiences broadcast on television. We cannot absolutely fix a car, build a fountain in the backyard, travel to Peru and investigate ancient ruins, or remodel our neighbor's house.
ref: The postmodern approach to learning offers the freedom from absolutes. There is no one good way to learn. In fact, there is not one good thing to learn.Learning takes place in the experience between the learner and the knowledge presented. Our current experience with all the do-it-yourself and information presenting, learning-based television shows illustrates this point. So many of us find ourselves watching a television show that informs us of a process or experience in which we will never participate or apply that knowledge. We will never overhaul a car, build a fountain in our backyard, travel to Peru to examine ancient ruins, or remodel our neighbour's house.

src: ポストモダンの学習方法は、絶対的な考え方から解放されています。優れた学習方法は1つではありません。 実際、学ぶべきことは1つとは限りません。学習とは、学習者と提示された知識の間で経験というかたちで発生するものです。 日曜大工と情報提示、学習ベースのテレビ番組すべてからこれまでに得た私たちの経験がこの点を物語っています。 ですから、私たちの多くは、テレビ番組で放映されるプロセスや経験に私たちが参加したり知識を応用したりはできないことに気づくわけです。 車を点検整備したり、裏庭に噴水を作ったり、ペルーに旅行して古代遺跡を調査したり、隣人の家を改造したりすることは絶対にありません。
mt: Postmodern learning methods are freed from absolute thinking. There is no one great way to learn. In fact, there is no one thing to learn. Learning is an experience that happens between the learner and the knowledge presented. Our experiences with carpentry and information presentation, and learning-based television programs tell us this. So, we realize that we cannot participate in or apply knowledge to the processes or experiences broadcast on television. We cannot absolutely fix a car, build a fountain in the backyard, travel to Peru and investigate ancient ruins, or remodel our neighbor's house.
ref: The postmodern approach to learning offers the freedom from absolutes. There is no one good way to learn. In fact, there is not one good thing to learn.Learning takes place in the experience between the learner and the knowledge presented. Our current experience with all the do-it-yourself and information presenting, learning-based television shows illustrates this point. So many of us find ourselves watching a television show that informs us of a process or experience in which we will never participate or apply that knowledge. We will never overhaul a car, build a fountain in our backyard, travel to Peru to examine ancient ruins, or remodel our neighbour's house.

src: 睡眠の中断とは、通常の睡眠時間中に意図的に目を覚まし、しばらく（10～60分）してから眠りに落ちるプロセスです。 これは、比較的静かな目覚まし時計を使って、完全に目を覚まさずに意識を呼び戻すことで簡単にできます。 無意識のうちにアラームを止めてしまうことに気がついたら、部屋の反対側に時計を置いて、ベッドから出なければ止められないようにする手があります。 バイオリズムに基づくその他の手段としては、睡眠前に水分（特に水や利尿作用のあるお茶）を多めに摂って、排尿するために起きざるをえない状況にするなどです。
mt: Sleep interruption is a process of waking up intentionally during normal sleeping hours, and then falling asleep again after a short period (10-60 minutes). This can be easily done by using a relatively quiet alarm clock without fully waking up and bringing back your consciousness. If you realize that you have stopped the alarm unconsciously, you can put the clock on the opposite side of the room so that you cannot stop it without getting out of bed. Other methods based on bio-rhythms include drinking a lot of water (especially water and diuretic tea) before sleeping, so that you have to wake up to urinate.
ref: Sleep interruption is the process of purposefully awakening during your normal sleep period and falling asleep a short time later (10–60 minutes). This can be easily done by using a relatively quiet alarm clock to bring you to consciousness without fully waking you. If you find yourself resetting the clock in your sleep, it can be placed on the other side of the room, forcing you to get out of bed to turn it off. Other biorhythm-based options involve drinking lots of fluid (particularly water or tea, a known diuretic) prior to sleep, forcing one to get up to urinate.

src: 睡眠の中断とは、通常の睡眠時間中に意図的に目を覚まし、しばらく（10～60分）してから眠りに落ちるプロセスです。 これは、比較的静かな目覚まし時計を使って、完全に目を覚まさずに意識を呼び戻すことで簡単にできます。 無意識のうちにアラームを止めてしまうことに気がついたら、部屋の反対側に時計を置いて、ベッドから出なければ止められないようにする手があります。 バイオリズムに基づくその他の手段としては、睡眠前に水分（特に水や利尿作用のあるお茶）を多めに摂って、排尿するために起きざるをえない状況にするなどです。

src: 人工的に誘導された明晰夢を頻繁に経験しすぎると、非常に疲弊する可能性があると考える人もいます。 この現象が起きる主な理由は、明晰夢でレム睡眠時間が引き延ばされた結果です。 一晩あたりのレム睡眠が減ると、実際の睡眠を経験して体が回復するこの状態は、問題と言えるほど頻度が低下します。 これは、20～30分おきに起きてテレビを見るのと同じくらい疲れます。 この効果は、脳が一晩にはっきりした夢を見ようとする回数に依存しています。
mt: Some people believe that experiencing lucid dreams too often can be very exhausting. The main reason for this phenomenon is that the REM sleep time is extended during lucid dreams. If the REM sleep is reduced per night, the state in which the body recovers by actually sleeping is not frequent enough to be a problem. This effect is similar to watching TV every 20-30 minutes, which is also very tiring. This effect depends on the number of times the brain tries to have a lucid dream per night.
ref: Some people believe that experiencing many artificially induced lucid dreams often enough can be very exhausting. The main reason for this phenomenon is the result of the lucid dreams expanding the length of time between REM states. With fewer REMs per night, this state in which you experience actual sleep and your body recovers becomes infrequent enough to become a problem. This is just as exhausting as if you were to wake up every twenty or thirty minutes and watch TV. The effect is dependent on how often your brain attempts to lucidly dream per night.

src: 人工的に誘導された明晰夢を頻繁に経験しすぎると、非常に疲弊する可能性があると考える人もいます。 この現象が起きる主な理由は、明晰夢でレム睡眠時間が引き延ばされた結果です。 一晩あたりのレム睡眠が減ると、実際の睡眠を経験して体が回復するこの状態は、問題と言えるほど頻度が低下します。 これは、20～30分おきに起きてテレビを見るのと同じくらい疲れます。 この効果は、脳が一晩にはっきりした夢を見ようとする回数に依存しています。

The main reason for this phenomenon is the result of the lucid dreams expanding the length of time between REM states. With fewer REMs per night, this state in which you experience actual sleep and your body recovers becomes infrequent enough to become a problem. src: バーチャルチームは、従来のチームと同じ水準の卓越性が求められますが、微妙な違いがあります。 バーチャルチームのメンバーは、直属の物理的なグループの窓口として機能することがよくあります。 バーチャルチームはタイムゾーンに合わせて会議を開くことがありますが、そうしたことは現地の経営陣に理解されにくいので、メンバーは従来のチームメンバーよりも高い自律性を有することが多くなります。 真の「見えないチーム」（Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109）の存在もまた、バーチャルチームの独自の要素である。 「見えないチーム」とは、各員の上長にあたる経営陣のことです。見えないチームは、各員にとっての基準を定めます。
mt: Virtual teams are expected to perform at the same level of excellence as traditional teams, but with subtle differences. Virtual team members often function as the window to the physical group. Virtual teams may hold meetings at different time zones, but this is often not understood by the local management, so members tend to have higher levels of autonomy than traditional team members. The presence of a "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of virtual teams. The invisible team is the management that each member reports to. The invisible team sets the standards for each member.
ref: Virtual teams are held to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences. Virtual team members often function as the point of contact for their immediate physical group. They often have more autonomy than conventional team members as their teams may meet according to varying time zones which may not be understood by their local management. The presence of a true “invisible team” (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique component of a virtual team. The “invisible team” is the management team to which each of the members report. The invisible team sets the standards for each member.

src: バーチャルチームは、従来のチームと同じ水準の卓越性が求められますが、微妙な違いがあります。 バーチャルチームのメンバーは、直属の物理的なグループの窓口として機能することがよくあります。 バーチャルチームはタイムゾーンに合わせて会議を開くことがありますが、そうしたことは現地の経営陣に理解されにくいので、メンバーは従来のチームメンバーよりも高い自律性を有することが多くなります。 真の「見えないチーム」（Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109）の存在もまた、バーチャルチームの独自の要素である。 「見えないチーム」とは、各員の上長にあたる経営陣のことです。見えないチームは、各員にとっての基準を定めます。

src: コンテンツ理論は、人の心をくすぐるものやアピールするものを見つけることを中心にしています。 これらの理論は、人々が成人期を迎えて成熟するにつれて内在化した特定のニーズや欲望を抱いていることを示唆しています。 これらの理論では、ある種の人々が日常的に特定のことをしたがる動機について、そして彼らに特定のことをさせる、あるいはさせない環境要因について考察します。 通説とされる2つコンテンツ理論はマズローの欲求段階説とヘルツベルクの二要因理論です。
mt: Content theory focuses on finding things that tickle or appeal to people's hearts. These theories suggest that as people mature into adulthood, they internalize specific needs or desires. These theories examine the motivation of certain people to do certain things on a daily basis, and the environmental factors that enable or prevent them from doing so. The two content theories that are most often cited are Maslow's hierarchy of needs and Herzberg's two-factor theory.
ref: Content theories are centered on finding what makes people tick or appeals to them. These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires which have been internalized as they mature to adulthood. These theories look at what it is about certain people that make them want the things that they do and what things in their environment will make them do or not do certain things. Two popular content theories are Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs Theory and Hertzberg's Two Factor Theory.

src: 「三分割法」 は、軽視する人もいるようですが、映像の秩序を保ちながらダイナミズムを生み出すシンプルな目安です。 主な被写体を配置すべき最も効果的な位置は、画像を縦横3分の1ずつに分割した線の交点に囲まれた部分（例を参照）とされます。
mt: 3-Point Rule is a simple guide to place the main subject in the most effective position, which is the intersection of the lines dividing the image into thirds vertically and horizontally (see example).
ref: The much-abused and often-ridiculed rule of thirds is a simple guideline creating dynamism while keeping a measure of order in an image. It states that the most effective place for the main subject is at the intersection of lines dividing the image into thirds vertically and horizontally (see example).

src: 例えば、世界で最も普及している静止画写真のフィルム形式は35 mmで、これはアナログフィルム時代の終わり頃には主流のフィルムサイズでした。 現在も生産されていますが、それ以上に重要なのは、そのアスペクト比がデジタルカメラのイメージセンサーのフォーマットを継承していることです。 紛らわしいのですが、35 mm判は実際には幅36 mm、高さ24 mmというサイズです。 そのため、この形式のアスペクト比（12で割って最も単純な全数比を求める）は3:2と言われています。 一般的な記録形式（例えば、APS系の記録形式）の多くは、このアスペクト比と同等かそれに近いものです。
mt: For example, the most popular still photo film format in the world is 35 mm, which was the standard film size in the analog film era. It is still produced, but more importantly, its aspect ratio is inherited by the image sensor format of digital cameras. Confusingly, 35 mm format is actually 36 mm wide and 24 mm high. Therefore, this format's aspect ratio (the simplest whole number ratio by dividing by 12) is 3:2. Many of the common recording formats (such as APS recording formats) are similar to or equal to this aspect ratio.
ref: For example, the most common still image photography format in the world is 35mm, which was the dominant film size at the close of the analog film era. It is still produced today, but more importantly its aspect ratio has been inherited by digital camera image sensor formats. The 35mm format is actually, somewhat confusingly, 36mm in width by 24mm in height. The aspect ratio of this format (dividing by twelve to obtain the simplest whole-number ratio) is therefore said to be 3:2. Many common formats (APS family of formats, for example) are equal to or closely approximate this aspect ratio.

src: ズームレンズの欠点は、焦点距離の範囲に対応するうえで必要な焦点距離の複雑さとレンズ素子の数が、焦点レンズよりもはるかに多いことです。 レンズメーカーが生産するレンズが高い基準に達するにつれ、これは問題ではなくなりつつあります。 これでズームレンズは固定焦点距離のレンズに匹敵する画質を実現しました。 ズームレンズのもう1つの欠点は、多くの製品ではレンズの絞り値（速度）が低いことです。 そのため、安価なズームレンズはフラッシュを使わないと低照度の状態では使いづらくなります。
mt: The main drawback of zoom lenses is that the range of focal lengths requires a greater number of focal lengths and lens elements than fixed focal length lenses. As lens manufacturers produce lenses that meet higher standards, this is becoming less of a problem. This has now achieved the quality of fixed focal length lenses. Another drawback of zoom lenses is that many products have a low aperture (speed) of the lens. Therefore, cheap zoom lenses are difficult to use in low light conditions without a flash.
ref: The disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the focal complexity and number of lens elements required to achieve a range of focal lengths is much greater than for prime lenses. This is becoming less of an issue as lens manufacturers achieve higher standards in lens production. This has allowed zoom lenses to produce pictures of a quality comparable to that achieved by lenses with fixed focal length. Another disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the maximum aperture (the speed) of the lens is usually lower. This makes inexpensive zoom lenses hard to use in low-light conditions without a flash.

src: ズームレンズの欠点は、焦点距離の範囲に対応するうえで必要な焦点距離の複雑さとレンズ素子の数が、焦点レンズよりもはるかに多いことです。 レンズメーカーが生産するレンズが高い基準に達するにつれ、これは問題ではなくなりつつあります。 これでズームレンズは固定焦点距離のレンズに匹敵する画質を実現しました。 ズームレンズのもう1つの欠点は、多くの製品ではレンズの絞り値（速度）が低いことです。 そのため、安価なズームレンズはフラッシュを使わないと低照度の状態では使いづらくなります。

src: 神秘主義は、究極の現実、神性、霊的真理、または神との交信、同一性、または意識的な意識を追求する哲学なしい宗教上の思想です。 信者は、神の現実・神性または神に関わる直接体験、直観、または洞察を追求します。 信者たちは、ある種の生き方や、そうした経験を育むことを目的とした実践を追求しています。 神秘主義は、特に平穏、洞察、至福、あるいは恍惚といった性格の独特な意識状態の直接的で個人的な経験に重点を置くことによって、他の宗教的な信念や崇拝の形態と区別することができます。
mt: Mysticism is a philosophy or religion that seeks to understand the ultimate reality, divinity, spiritual truth, or communion, identity, or conscious awareness with God. Followers seek direct experience, intuition, or insight into the reality, divinity, or God. Followers seek to cultivate practices that aim to achieve such experiences. Mysticism is distinguished from other religious beliefs and practices by its emphasis on direct, personal, and unique experiences of such qualities as tranquility, insight, bliss, or ecstasy.
ref: Mysticism is the pursuit of communion with, identity with, or conscious awareness of an ultimate reality, divinity, spiritual truth, or God. The believer seeks a direct experience, intuition, or insight into divine reality/the deity or dieties. Followers pursue certain ways of living, or practices that are intended to nurture those experiences. Mysticism can be distinguished from other forms of religious belief and worship by its emphasis on the direct personal experience of a unique state of consciousness, particularly those of a peaceful, insightful, blissful, or even ecstatic character.

src: 神秘主義は、究極の現実、神性、霊的真理、または神との交信、同一性、または意識的な意識を追求する哲学なしい宗教上の思想です。 信者は、神の現実・神性または神に関わる直接体験、直観、または洞察を追求します。 信者たちは、ある種の生き方や、そうした経験を育むことを目的とした実践を追求しています。 神秘主義は、特に平穏、洞察、至福、あるいは恍惚といった性格の独特な意識状態の直接的で個人的な経験に重点を置くことによって、他の宗教的な信念や崇拝の形態と区別することができます。

src: 19世紀から20世紀まで長い間、ニュージーランドに最初に入植した先住民はマオリ族で、恐鳥（モア）と呼ばれる巨大な鳥を狩っていたと考えられていました。 その後、マオリ族が大船団でポリネシアから移住し、モリオーリ族からニュージーランドを奪い取って農耕社会を築いたという説が定着しました。 しかし、新しい証拠によると、モリオリ族はニュージーランドからチャタム諸島に移住してきた本土のマオリ族集団であり、独自の平和的な文化を発展させてきたとされます。 チャタム島にはニュージーランドから移ってきた別の部族も暮らしており、それがマオリ族でした。 彼らは自らをモリオリと呼び、何度か小競り合いがありましたが、最終的にはモリオリは全滅してしまいました。
mt: 19th and early 20th century, the first indigenous people to settle in New Zealand were the Maori, who hunted the giant bird known as the moa. Later, the Maori came to New Zealand in a large fleet from Polynesia and took over the land from the Moriori, building an agricultural society. However, new evidence suggests that the Moriori were a mainland Maori group who migrated to the Chatham Islands from New Zealand and developed their own peaceful culture. There were other tribes from New Zealand living on the Chatham Islands. They called themselves Moriori and had occasional skirmishes, but eventually the Moriori were wiped out.
ref: For a long time during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, it was believed the first inhabitants of New Zealand were the Maori people, who hunted giant birds called moas. The theory then established the idea that the Maori people migrated from Polynesia in a Great Fleet and took New Zealand from the Moriori, establishing an agricultural society. However, new evidence suggests that the Moriori were a group of mainland Maori who migrated from New Zealand to the Chatham Islands, developing their own distinctive, peaceful culture. There was also another tribe on the Chatham islands these were Maori who migrated away from New Zealand. They called themselves the Moriori there were a few skirmishes and in the end, the Moriori were wiped out

src: 19世紀から20世紀まで長い間、ニュージーランドに最初に入植した先住民はマオリ族で、恐鳥（モア）と呼ばれる巨大な鳥を狩っていたと考えられていました。 その後、マオリ族が大船団でポリネシアから移住し、モリオーリ族からニュージーランドを奪い取って農耕社会を築いたという説が定着しました。 しかし、新しい証拠によると、モリオリ族はニュージーランドからチャタム諸島に移住してきた本土のマオリ族集団であり、独自の平和的な文化を発展させてきたとされます。 チャタム島にはニュージーランドから移ってきた別の部族も暮らしており、それがマオリ族でした。 彼らは自らをモリオリと呼び、何度か小競り合いがありましたが、最終的にはモリオリは全滅してしまいました。

ref: For a long time during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, it was believed the first inhabitants of New Zealand were the Maori people, who hunted giant birds called moas. The theory then established the idea that the Maori people migrated from Polynesia in a Great Fleet and took New Zealand from the Moriori, establishing an agricultural society. However, new evidence suggests that the Moriori were a group of mainland Maori who migrated from New Zealand to the Chatham Islands, developing their own distinctive, peaceful culture. There was also another tribe on the Chatham islands these were Maori who migrated away from New Zealand. They called themselves the Moriori there were a few skirmishes and in the end, the Moriori were wiped out

src: ピュアランド折り紙とは、一度に折れるのは1か所で、逆折りなどの複雑な折り方はできず、すべての折り目が直線的であるという制約のある折り紙です。 1970年代にジョン・スミス氏によって、折り紙の経験が浅い人や手先の不器用な人のために開発されました。
mt: Pureland origami is a type of origami that can be folded in one place, and does not allow for complex folds such as reverse folds, and all folds are linear. It was developed in the 1970s by John Smith for people with little experience in origami or who are not dexterous.
ref: Pureland origami is origami with the restriction that only one fold may be done at a time, more complex folds like reverse folds are not allowed, and all folds have straightforward locations. It was developed by John Smith in the 1970s to help inexperienced folders or those with limited motor skills.

src: インダス渓谷文明は、北西インド亜大陸の青銅器時代の文明で、現代のパキスタンの大部分とインド北西部と北東アフガニスタンの一部の地域を包含していました。 この文明はインダス川の流域で栄え、その名の由来となりました。 一部の学者は、今では干上がったサラスヴァティ川の流域にも文明は存在したと推測し、インダス・サラスヴァティ文明と呼ぶのが適切であるとしていますが、一方で、1920年代に発掘された最初の遺跡であるハラッパにちなんで、ハラッパン文明と呼ぶ人もいます。
mt: The Indus Valley Civilization was a Bronze Age civilization in northwestern South Asia, dating from the 33rd to 13th centuries BCE. In the Indus Valley, this urban culture flourished in the major river valleys without having an empire, relying on agricultural surplus to sustain the urban population. The Indus Valley Civilization was one of the largest early urban civilizations, and one of the world's first state-level civilizations. It is also one of the world's earliest urban settlements. The Indus Valley Civilization was first identified in 1921 at Harappa, in the Punjab region and was first identified as early as 1842. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Harappan Civilization, after its first excavated site, and as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, after the Indus and Sarasvati Rivers, which are believed to have been the primary rivers of the civilization.
ref: The Indus Valley Civilization was a Bronze Age civilisation in the northwest Indian subcontinent encompassing most of modern-day Pakistan and some regions in northwest India and northeast Afghanistan. The civilisation flourished in the basins of the Indus River wherefore it derives its name. Although some scholars speculate that since the civilisation also existed in the basins of the now dried up Sarasvati River, it should be aptly called the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, while some call it the Harappan Civilization after Harappa, the first of its sites to be excavated in the 1920s.

src: 欲や利己主義は常に身近なものですが、多数派が利益を得るときには、利己的に振る舞うことで短期的には常に多くの利益を得られるというのが協力の本質です。 うまくいけば、長期的な最善の選択肢は互いに協力し合うことだとほとんどの人が気づくでしょう。
mt: It is always close at hand, but when the majority benefits, acting selfishly is always the best way to get the most short-term benefits. If it works out, most people will realize that the best long-term choice is to cooperate with each other.
ref: Greed and selfishness will always be with us and it is the nature of cooperation that when the majority benefit there will always be more to gain in the short term by acting selfishly Hopefully, most people will realise that their long term best option is to work together with others.

src: アメリカ帝国主義による戦争でフィリピン征服にかかった費用をフィリピン人が負担したのです。 彼らは、支出の大部分を賄うためにアメリカの植民地政権への納税を予後なくされ、ウォール街の銀行を通してフィリピン政府の名前で売りに出されていた債券の利子も払わざるを得ませんでした。 もちろん、長期にわたるフィリピン人の搾取から得られる超過利潤は、米国帝国主義の基礎利益を成すものだったでしょう。
mt: The cost of the war of American imperialism to conquer the Philippines was borne by the Filipinos. They were taxed to pay for the bulk of the expenditure, and were also forced to pay the interest on the bonds sold by the Philippine government through Wall Street banks, which were collateralized by the Philippines. Of course, the super profits derived from the long-term exploitation of the Filipinos would have been the basis of American imperialism.
ref: The war expenditures of U.S. imperialism in the conquest of the Philippines were paid for by the Filipino people themselves. They were compelled to pay taxes to the U.S. colonial regime to defray a major part of the expenditures and the interest on bonds floated in the name of the Philippine government through the Wall Street banking houses. Of course, the superprofits derived from the protracted exploitation of the Filipino people would constitute the basic gains of U.S. imperialism.

src: テンプル騎士団を理解するためには、その秩序が生まれた文脈を理解する必要があります。 この事件が起きた時代は中世盛期と呼ばれ、一般的にヨーロッパ史で11世紀、12世紀、13世紀（西暦1000年～1300年）の期間が相当します。 中世盛期は歴史上の時代区分として中世前期と中世後期の間の時代とされ、中世後期は1500年までに終了したと考えるのが慣例である。
mt: To understand the Knights Templar, one must understand the context in which the order was born. This event took place during the High Middle Ages, which are generally considered to be the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries (1000–1300 AD). The High Middle Ages are considered to be the period between the Early Middle Ages and the Late Middle Ages, and the Late Middle Ages are considered to have ended by 1500.
ref: To understand the Templars one must understand the context that prompted the creation of the order. The age where the events took place is commonly referred as the High Middle Ages the period of European history in the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries (AD 1000–1300). The High Middle Ages were preceded by the Early Middle Ages and followed by the Late Middle Ages, which by convention ends around 1500.

src: ローマ帝国の軍国主義的な性質は、医療の進歩に役立ちました。 医師はアウグストゥス皇帝によって募集され始め、戦いの余波で活用される最初のローマの医療隊を形成しました。 外科医らにはケシの種子から抽出したモルヒネやヘルバネの種子から抽出したスコポラミンなど、各種の鎮静剤の知識がありました。 彼らは、患者を壊疽から救うための四肢切断術、血流を止める止血帯、そして動脈クランプにも精通していました。 ローマ帝国は何世紀にもわたって医学の分野に大きな利益をもたらし、私たちが今日授かっている知識の多くを生み出しました。
mt: The militaristic nature of the Roman Empire helped advance medical care. Physicians were recruited by Emperor Augustus and formed the first Roman medical corps to be used in the aftermath of war. They were knowledgeable in various sedatives, such as opium from poppy seeds and scopolamine from henbane seeds. They were also skilled in amputation to save patients from gangrene, tourniquets to stop blood flow, and arterial clamps. The Roman Empire brought great benefits to the field of medicine for centuries and gave rise to much of the knowledge we have today.
ref: The militaristic nature of the Roman empire aided in the development of medical advances. Doctors began to be recruited by Emperor Augustus and even formed the first Roman Medical Corps for use in the aftermath of battles. Surgeons had knowledge of various sedatives including morphine from extracts of poppy seeds and scopolamine from herbane seeds. They became proficient at amputation to save patients from gangrene as well as tourniquets and arterial clamps to stem blood flow. Over multiple centuries, the Roman empire led to great gains in the field of medicine and formed much of the knowledge we know today.

src: 視覚、つまり見る能力は、視覚系の感覚器官（つまり目）に依存しています。 眼の構造は、生体の要件に応じて、ごく単純なものから非常に複雑なものまでさまざまです。 構造が異なれば機能も異なり、感じ取る波長が異なり、視力の程度も異なります。また、それらの構造には入力信号を理解するためのさまざまな処理や機能に応じた個数が必要になります。
ref: Vision, or the ability to see depends on visual system sensory organs or eyes. There are many different constructions of eyes, ranging in complexity depending on the requirements of the organism. The different constructions have different capabilities, are sensitive to different wave-lengths and have differing degrees of acuity, also they require different processing to make sense of the input and different numbers to work optimally.

src: シーク教はインド亜大陸に由来する宗教です。ヒンドゥー教の伝統の中での宗派分裂から15世紀にパンジャブ地方で発祥しました。 シーク教徒たちは、ヒンドゥー教のルーツや伝統を尊重しながらも、自らの信仰をヒンドゥー教とは別個の宗教と見なしてます。 シーク教徒は自らの宗教をグルマットと呼び、これはパンジャブ語で「教祖の道」という意味です。教祖はあらゆるインド宗教に共通の基本的側面ですが、シーク教では特に重要性を帯び、シーク教信仰の中心を形成すしています。 シーク教は15世紀にグル・ナーナク（Guru Nanak、1469～1539）によって創設されました。その後、さらに9人のグルが後継者となりました。
mt: Sikhism is a religion that originated in the Indian subcontinent as a separation from the traditions of Hinduism. Sikhs respect the roots and traditions of Hinduism, but consider their own faith to be a separate religion. Sikhs call their religion Gurmat, which means "the way of the Guru" in Punjabi. The Guru is a common basic aspect of all Indian religions, but in Sikhism it is especially important, forming the center of Sikh belief. Sikhism was founded in the 15th century by Guru Nanak (1469–1539), who was followed by nine other Gurus.
ref: "Sikhism is a religion from the Indian sub-continent. It originated in the Punjab region during the 15th century from a sectarian split within the Hindu tradition. Sikhs consider their faith to be a separate religion from Hinduism though they acknowledge its Hindu roots and traditions. Sikhs call their religion Gurmat, which is Punjabi for ""way of the guru"". The guru is a fundamental aspect of all Indian religions but in Sikhism has taken on an importance that forms the core of Sikh beliefs. The religion was founded in the 15th century by Guru Nanak (1469–1539). There followed in succession a further nine gurus."

src: 注意力欠如障害とは、「神経学的症候群であり、その古典的定義は衝動性、注意力散漫、多動またはエネルギー過多の3つの症状です。 これは教育的な意味での学習障害ではなく、医学的な意味での学習障害であり、すべての子供の3～5%、おそらく200万人ものアメリカ人の子供に影響を与えています。 ADDを持つ子供は、学校の勉強などに集中することは難しいものの、ゲームをしたり、好きなアニメを見たり、句読点のない文章を書いたりするような、楽しいことには集中できるのです。 こういった子供たちは、通常の方法では脳が刺激されないため、脳を刺激しようとして「危険な行動に出たり、喧嘩をしたり、権威にたて突いたり」して、さまざまなトラブルに巻き込まれる傾向があります。 ADDは仲間との関係に影響を及ぼします。ADDを持つ子がなぜそのように振る舞い、なぜそのように字を綴り、なぜ成熟度が違うのかを他の子供たちは理解できないためです。
mt: Attention Deficit Disorder is a neurological syndrome, defined classically by three symptoms: impulsivity, inattention, and hyperactivity or energy excess. This is not an educational definition of learning disability, but a medical definition of learning disability, affecting 3-5% of all children, perhaps 200 million American children. ADD children have difficulty concentrating on schoolwork, but can concentrate on fun things like playing games, watching their favorite anime, or writing sentences without punctuation. These children tend to get into trouble by "acting out" or fighting or defying authority because their brains are not stimulated in the usual way. ADD affects relationships with peers. Other children do not understand why ADD children behave the way they do, why they write the way they do, why they are not mature.
ref: "Attention Deficit Disorder ""is a neurological syndrome whose classic defining triad of symptoms including impulsivity, distractibility, and hyperactivity or excess energy"". It is not a learning disability, it is a learning disorder; it ""affects 3 to 5 percent of all children, perhaps as many as 2 million American children"". Children with ADD have a hard time focusing on things like school work, but they can concentrate on things they enjoy doing like playing games or watching their favorite cartoons or writing sentences without punctuation. These children tend to get into a lot of trouble, because they ""engage in risky behaviors, get into fights, and challenge authority"" in order to stimulate their brain, since their brain can not be stimulated by normal methods. ADD affects relationships with other peers because other children can not understand why they act the way that they do or why they spell they way they do or that their maturity level is different."

src: 注意力欠如障害とは、「神経学的症候群であり、その古典的定義は衝動性、注意力散漫、多動またはエネルギー過多の3つの症状です。 これは教育的な意味での学習障害ではなく、医学的な意味での学習障害であり、すべての子供の3～5%、おそらく200万人ものアメリカ人の子供に影響を与えています。 ADDを持つ子供は、学校の勉強などに集中することは難しいものの、ゲームをしたり、好きなアニメを見たり、句読点のない文章を書いたりするような、楽しいことには集中できるのです。 こういった子供たちは、通常の方法では脳が刺激されないため、脳を刺激しようとして「危険な行動に出たり、喧嘩をしたり、権威にたて突いたり」して、さまざまなトラブルに巻き込まれる傾向があります。 ADDは仲間との関係に影響を及ぼします。ADDを持つ子がなぜそのように振る舞い、なぜそのように字を綴り、なぜ成熟度が違うのかを他の子供たちは理解できないためです。
mt: Attention Deficit Disorder is a neurological syndrome, defined classically by three symptoms: impulsivity, inattention, and hyperactivity or energy excess. This is not an educational definition of learning disability, but a medical definition of learning disability, affecting 3-5% of all children, perhaps 200 million American children. ADD children have difficulty concentrating on schoolwork, but can concentrate on fun things like playing games, watching their favorite anime, or writing sentences without punctuation. These children tend to get into trouble by "acting out" or fighting or defying authority because their brains are not stimulated in the usual way. ADD affects relationships with peers. Other children do not understand why ADD children behave the way they do, why they write the way they do, why they are not mature.
ref: "Attention Deficit Disorder ""is a neurological syndrome whose classic defining triad of symptoms including impulsivity, distractibility, and hyperactivity or excess energy"". It is not a learning disability, it is a learning disorder; it ""affects 3 to 5 percent of all children, perhaps as many as 2 million American children"". Children with ADD have a hard time focusing on things like school work, but they can concentrate on things they enjoy doing like playing games or watching their favorite cartoons or writing sentences without punctuation. These children tend to get into a lot of trouble, because they ""engage in risky behaviors, get into fights, and challenge authority"" in order to stimulate their brain, since their brain can not be stimulated by normal methods. ADD affects relationships with other peers because other children can not understand why they act the way that they do or why they spell they way they do or that their maturity level is different."

src: プロジェクトベースの学習で学習はより簡単かつ興味深いものになるはずですが、スキャフォールディングはその1歩先を行きます。 スキャフォールドは学習の方法ではなく、新しいコンピュータプログラムを使ったり、新しいプロジェクトを開始したり、新しい学習体験をしている人をサポートするためのものです。 スキャフォールディングにはバーチャルとリアルの両方があります。言い換えれば、教師はスキャフォールディングの一形態であり、Microsoft Officeのクリップ人形もそうです。 バーチャル・スキャフォールドはこのソフトウェアに組み込まれており、学生が1人では難しいと思われる手順についての質問、指示、説明できるようにすることを目的としています。
mt: Project-based learning is supposed to make learning easier and more interesting, but scaffolding is one step ahead. Scaffolding is not a method of learning, but a new computer program or a new project to start or a new learning experience to support people who are doing it. Scaffolding can be virtual or real. In other words, teachers are one form of scaffolding and the Microsoft Office clipart is another. Virtual scaffolding is built into this software to help students ask, direct, and explain steps that they might find difficult on their own.
ref: While project based learning should make learning easier and more interesting, scaffolding goes a step beyond. Scaffolding is not a method of learning but rather an aid that provides support to individuals whom are undergoing a new learning experience such as using a new computer program or beginning a new project. Scaffolds can be both virtual and real, in other words, a teacher is a form of scaffold but so is the little paperclip man in Microsoft Office. Virtual Scaffolds are internalized in the software and are meant to question, prompt, and explain procedures that may have been to challenging for the student to handle alone.

src: MySpaceは、米国で3番目に人気のあるウェブサイトで、現在5千4百万人のプロフィールが存在します。 こういったウェブサイトは特に教育環境において大いに注目を集めています。 これらのウェブサイトは、特に教育現場で多くの注目を集めています。ブログ、動画、写真、その他の機能を盛り込んだクラスページを簡単に設定することができるなどの優れた側面があります。 このページは、ウェブアドレスを1つ入力するだけで簡単にアクセスでき、キーボードの使用や複雑な綴りが苦手な学生にとって覚えやすく、入力しやすい仕様になっています。 読みやすくカスタマイズしたり、表示色を自由に増減できます。
mt: MySpace is the third most popular website in the United States, with over 54 million profiles. These websites are gaining a lot of attention in the educational environment. They are gaining a lot of attention in the educational environment. They have great features such as setting up a class page with blogs, videos, photos, and other features. This page can be accessed by simply entering one web address, making it easy for students who are not good at using keyboards or complicated spelling. It is easy to read and customize, and you can increase or decrease the display color.
ref: MySpace is the third most popular website used in the United States and has 54 million profiles currently. These websites have gotten a lot of attention, especially in the education setting. There are positive aspects to these websites, which include, being able to easily setup a class page which can include blogs, videos, photos, and other features. This page can easily be accessed by providing just one web address, which makes it easy to remember and easy to type in for students who may have trouble using the keyboard or with spelling. It can be customized to make it easy to read and also with as much or little color as desired.

src: しかし、1956年6月にポーランドで食糧不足と賃金削減に抗議する労働者たちが暴動を起こし、それが共産主義に対する一般抗議行動に変わったとき、クルシチョフの公約が試されることになりました。 最終的には、クルシチョフは秩序を回復するために戦車を送り込みましたが、一部の経済的な要求に道を譲り、人気のあるウラジスラフ・ゴムルカを新首相に任命することに合意しました。
mt: However, when workers in Poland protested food shortages and wage cuts in June 1956, their riots turned into a general protest against communism.  Khrushchev's promises were put to the test.  Ultimately, Khrushchev sent in tanks to restore order, but agreed to some economic demands and appointed the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as prime minister.
ref: However, in June 1956, Krushchev's promises were put to the test when riots in Poland, where workers were protesting against food shortages and wage cuts, turned into a general protest against Communism. Although in the end, Krushchev sent in tanks to restore order, he did give way to some economic demands and agreed to appoint the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as the new prime minister.

src: しかし、1956年6月にポーランドで食糧不足と賃金削減に抗議する労働者たちが暴動を起こし、それが共産主義に対する一般抗議行動に変わったとき、クルシチョフの公約が試されることになりました。 最終的には、クルシチョフは秩序を回復するために戦車を送り込みましたが、一部の経済的な要求に道を譲り、人気のあるウラジスラフ・ゴムルカを新首相に任命することに合意しました。
mt: However, when workers in Poland protested food shortages and wage cuts in June 1956, their riots turned into a general protest against communism.  Khrushchev's promises were put to the test.  Ultimately, Khrushchev sent in tanks to restore order, but agreed to some economic demands and appointed the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as prime minister.
ref: However, in June 1956, Krushchev's promises were put to the test when riots in Poland, where workers were protesting against food shortages and wage cuts, turned into a general protest against Communism. Although in the end, Krushchev sent in tanks to restore order, he did give way to some economic demands and agreed to appoint the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as the new prime minister.

src: 第二次世界大戦ではドイツは共通の敵であり、ソ連とアメリカの協力につながりました。終戦後、両国は制度やプロセス、そして文化の衝突により、反目し合うことになりました。 終戦から2年でかつての同盟国は敵国同士となり、やがて冷戦が始まりました。 その後それが40年間続き、アフリカからアジア、アフガニスタン、キューバなどの戦場で代理の軍隊による本物の戦いが繰り広げられることになりました。
mt: During World War II, Germany was a common enemy, and cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States ensued. After the war, the two countries became enemies due to institutional, procedural, and cultural clashes. Two years after the war, former allies became enemies, and the Cold War began. This continued for 40 years, and proxy armies fought real wars in Africa, Asia, Afghanistan, and Cuba.
ref: Germany was a common enemy in World War 2, leading to cooperation between the USSR and USA. With the end of the war the clashes of system, process and culture led to the countries falling out. With two years of the end of the war, the former allies were now enemies and the Cold War began. It was to last for the next 40 years and would be fought for real, by proxy armies, on battlefields from Africa to Asia, in Afghanistan, Cuba and many other places.

src: 神経系は、血液の流れを維持するために体の外に神経インパルスを送ることで恒常性を維持しています。 これらの神経インパルスは、体全体に非常に迅速に送られ、潜在的な脅威から体を安全に守るうえで役立ちます。
mt: The nervous system maintains homeostasis by sending nerve impulses to the body's exterior to maintain blood flow. These nerve impulses are sent very quickly throughout the entire body, helping to keep the body safe from potential threats.
ref: The Nervous System maintains homeostasis by sending nerve impulses through out the body to keep the flow of blood going as well as undisturbed. These nerve impulses can be sent so quickly throughout the body which helps keep the body safe from any potential threat.

src: ギザの大ピラミッドは、七不思議の中で唯一現存しているものです。 紀元前3世紀にエジプト人によって建設された大ピラミッドは、死んだファラオを祀るために建てられた数多くの大ピラミッド建築物の1つです。 エジプトの死者の谷に広がるギザ高原（ギザの墓地遺跡）には、何基ものピラミッド（その最大がギザの大ピラミッド）、いくつもの小さい墓、神殿、そして偉大なスフィンクスがあります。 大ピラミッドはファラオ・クフ王を称えて建てられた巨大な墓であり、その周囲にある小ピラミッド、墓、神殿の多くはクフ王の妻や家族を称えるものです。
mt: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the only one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World that still exists. The Great Pyramid of Giza was built by the Egyptians in the 3rd century BC to honor the dead Pharaoh. In the Valley of the Kings in Egypt, there are many pyramids (the largest of which is the Great Pyramid of Giza), small tombs, temples, and the great Sphinx. The Great Pyramid was built in honor of Pharaoh Khufu, and many of the smaller pyramids, tombs, and temples around it were built in honor of Khufu's wife and family.
ref: "The Great Pyramid at Giza is the only one of the seven wonders that is still standing today. Built by the Egyptians in the third century BCE, the Great Pyramid is one of many large pyramid structures built to honor dead Pharaoh. The Giza Plateau, or ""Giza Necropolis"" in the Egyptian Valley of the Dead contains several pyramids (of which the great pyramid is the largest), several small tombs, several temples, and the great Sphinx. The great pyramid was created to honor the Pharaoh Khufu, and many of the smaller pyramids, tombs, and temples were built to honor Khufu's wives and family members."

src: エフェソスにあったアルテミス神殿は、紀元前356年7月21日にヘロストラトゥスによる放火で破壊されてしまいました。 その話によれば、彼の動機は何としてでも名声を得ることでした。激怒したエフェソスの住民たちは、ヘロストラタスの名前を決して記録に残さないと発表しました。 後にギリシャの歴史家ストラボがその名を記したことから、現在の私たちの知るところとなっています。アレクサンダー大王が誕生した同じ夜に神殿は破壊されました。 アレクサンダーは王として神殿を再建するために出資を申し出ましたが、受け入れられませんでした。アレクサンダー大王の死後、紀元前323年に神殿が再建されました。
mt: The Temple of Artemis in Ephesus was destroyed by fire in 356 BC on July 21, by Herostatus. It was said that his motive was to gain fame. The residents of Ephesus were so angry that they announced that they would never record the name of Herostatus. Later, the Greek historian Strabo recorded his name, which is now known to us. The temple was destroyed on the same night that Alexander the Great was born. Alexander offered to fund the rebuilding of the temple as a king, but it was not accepted. After the death of Alexander the Great, the temple was rebuilt in 323 BC.
ref: The temple of Artemis at Ephesus was destroyed on July 21, 356 BCE in an act of arson committed by Herostratus. According to the story, his motivation was fame at any cost. The Ephesians, outraged, announced that Herostratus' name never be recorded. The Greek historian Strabo later noted the name, which is how we know today. The temple was destroyed on the same night that Alexander the Great was born. Alexander, as king, offered to pay to rebuild the temple, but his offer was denied. Later, after Alexander died, the temple was rebuilt in 323 BCE.

src: 最初に知られていた移動手段は歩行であり、人類の直立歩行は200万年前にホモ・エレクタス（「直立する人間」の意味）の出現時に始まりました。 直接の祖先であるアウストラロピテクスには、一定時間以上の直立歩行を続ける習慣はありませんでした。 サヘラントロプスは700万年前に早くも二本足で歩いた可能性がありますが、二足歩行の特性は、390～420万年前のオーストラロピテクスの化石で確認されています。
mt: The first known mode of locomotion was bipedalism, and upright bipedalism began with the appearance of Homo erectus about 2 million years ago. Direct ancestors Australopithecus did not have the habit of upright bipedalism for more than a certain period of time. Sahelanthropus may have been bipedal as early as 7 million years ago, but the characteristics of bipedalism are confirmed in the fossil of Australopithecus dating from 390 to 420 thousand years ago.
ref: The first known transportation was walking, humans began walking upright two million years ago with the emergence of Homo Erectus (meaning upright man). Their predecessors, the Australopithecus did not walk upright as habitually. Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2-3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have walked on two legs as early as seven million years ago.

src: 船舶で物資を輸送するのは、海を越えて人や物資を大量輸送する最も効率的な方法です。 従来より、海軍の仕事は、自国民や物資を輸送する能力を維持すると同時に、敵国民や物資を輸送する能力を確実に妨害することでした。 最近の最も注目すべき例として、第二次世界大戦の北大西洋作戦があります。アメリカはイギリスを助けるために大西洋を渡って人員や物資の輸送を試みました。 同時に、ドイツ海軍は主にUボートを使用して、この輸送を阻止しようとしていました。 連合国が敗れていたら、ドイツはおそらくヨーロッパの他国と同じように英国を征服できていたことでしょう。
mt: Shipping goods by ship is the most efficient way to transport large numbers of people and goods across the sea. Traditionally, the job of the navy has been to maintain the ability to transport one's own citizens and goods while simultaneously ensuring the ability to interfere with the transportation of enemy citizens and goods. One of the most notable recent examples is the Battle of the Atlantic during World War II. The United States was trying to transport personnel and goods across the Atlantic to help Britain. At the same time, the German navy was using primarily U-boats to try to block this transportation. If the Allies had lost, Germany would likely have been able to conquer Britain just as it did other countries in Europe.
ref: Using ships to transport goods is by far the most efficient way to move large amounts of people and goods across oceans. The job of navies has traditionally been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and goods, while at the same time, interfering with your enemy's ability to move his people and goods. One of the most noteworthy recent examples of this was the North Atlantic campaign of WWII. The Americans were trying to move men and materials across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain. At the same time, the German navy, using mainly U-boats, was trying to stop this traffic. Had the Allies failed, Germany probably would have been able to conquer Britain as it had the rest of Europe.

The job of navies has traditionally been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and goods, while at the same time, interfering with your enemy's ability to move his people and goods. One of the most noteworthy recent examples of this was the North Atlantic campaign of WWII. The Americans were trying to move men and materials across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain. At the same time, the German navy, using mainly U-boats, was trying to stop this traffic. Had the Allies failed, Germany probably would have been able to conquer Britain as it had the rest of Europe.

src: スポーク式ホイールの発明により、アッシリア軍の戦車は軽量、高速、強力になり、他国の兵士や戦車を振り切る体制が整いました。 恐ろしいクロスボウから放たれる矢は、敵兵の鎧を貫通しました。紀元前1000年頃にアッシリア人は最初の騎兵隊を導入した。 騎馬隊は、馬に乗って戦う軍隊です。当時まだ鞍や鐙は発明されていなかったため、アッシリアの騎兵たちは、馬の裸の背にまたがって戦いました。
mt: The invention of the spoked wheel made Assyrian tanks light, fast, and powerful, and they were able to outmaneuver other soldiers and tanks. The arrows shot from the terrifying crossbow penetrated enemy armor. Around 1000 BC, the Assyrians first introduced cavalry. Cavalry is a military force that fights on horseback. At the time, saddles and stirrups had not yet been invented, so Assyrian cavalry fought by straddling the bare backs of horses.
ref: The invention of spoke wheels made Assyrian chariots lighter, faster, and better prepared to outrun soldiers and other chariots. Arrows from their deadly crossbows could penetrate the armor of rival soldiers. About 1000 B.C., the Assyrians introduced the first cavalry. A cavalry is an army that fights on horseback. The saddle had not yet been invented, so the Assyrian cavalry fought on the bare backs of their horses.

src: バビロニア人は、神々のそれぞれに第一神殿を建て、それは神々の家とみなされていました。 人々は神々に生け贄を捧げ、祭司は儀式や祭りを通して神々の望みに応えようとしました。 各寺院には、開放的な中庭があり、その後に神官のみが入れる内宮がありました。 寺院の一部として、ジグラットと呼ばれるピラミッド型の特殊な塔が建てられることがありました。 塔の最上部は神のための特別な聖域でした。
mt: The Babylonians built a separate temple for each god, which were considered the god's house. People would sacrifice to the gods, and priests would try to fulfill the gods' wishes through rituals and festivals. Each temple had an open courtyard, followed by an inner sanctuary that only priests could enter. Some temples had ziggurats, pyramid-shaped special towers. The top of the tower was a special sanctuary for the god.
ref: The Babylonians built each of their gods a primary temple that was considered the home of the god. People would bring sacrifices to the gods and the priests would try to attend to the needs of the gods through ceremonies and festivals. Each temple had an open temple courtyard and then an inner sanctuary that only the priests could enter. Sometimes special pyramid shaped towers, called ziggurats, were built to be a part of the temples. The top of the tower was special sanctuary for the god.

src: そうです！ツタンカーメン王は、「少年王」と呼ばれることもあり、現代では最も有名な古代エジプトの王の1人です。 興味深いことに、彼は古代ではあまり重視されておらず、ほとんどの古代の王の名簿には記録がありません。 しかし、1922年に墓が発見されたことで、この若い王は一躍有名になりました。先人たちの墓の多くが墓荒らしに遭う中、この墓はほとんど手をつけかずで残っていたのです。 ツタンカーメンと一緒に埋葬された品目のほとんどは良い状態で保存されており、貴金属や希少な石で作られた工芸品などが何千とありました。
mt: Yes! Tutankhamun was one of the most famous ancient Egyptian kings, known as the "Boy King." Interestingly, he was not very well known in ancient times and was not recorded in most lists of ancient kings. However, when his tomb was discovered in 1922, this young king became famous. Most tombs of his predecessors had been looted, but this tomb was left largely untouched. Most of the items buried with Tutankhamun were well preserved, including thousands of works of art made of precious metals and rare stones.
ref: "Yes! King Tutankhamun, sometimes referred to as ""King Tut"" or ""The Boy King"", is one of the most well known ancient Egyptian kings in modern times. Interestingly, he was not considered to be very important in ancient times and was not recorded on most ancient king lists. However, the discovery of his tomb in 1922 made him a celebrity. While many tombs of the past were robbed, this tomb was left virtually undisturbed. Most of the items buried with Tutankhamun have been well preserved, including thousands of artefacts made from precious metals and rare stones."

src: 有名なギリシャ人の政治家、科学者、芸術家は大勢います。この古代文化の担い手としておそらく最も有名なのは、ギリシャ文学の2大傑作であるイリアスとオデュッセイアを作曲した伝説の盲目詩人ホメロスでしょう。 ソフォクレスやアリストファネスは、今でも人気の劇作家であり、彼らの戯曲は世界文学の最高傑作と称えられています。 もう1人の有名なギリシャ人は数学者ピタゴラスで、主に直角三角形の辺の関係についての有名な定理を発見したことで知られています。
mt: There are many famous Greek politicians, scientists, and artists.  Probably the most famous of these as the custodians of this ancient culture are the blind poet Homer, who composed the two great works of Greek literature, the Iliad and the Odyssey.  Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights, and their plays are considered among the greatest works of world literature.  Another famous Greek is the mathematician Pythagoras, who is known for his famous theorem about the relationship of the sides of a right triangle.
ref: We know many Greek politicians, scientists, and artists. Possibly the most known person of this culture is Homer, the legendary blind poet, who composed two masterpieces of Greek literature: the poems Iliad and Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights and their plays are considered to be among the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is a mathematician Pythagoras, mostly known for his famous theorem about relations of the sides of right triangles.

src: 有名なギリシャ人の政治家、科学者、芸術家は大勢います。この古代文化の担い手としておそらく最も有名なのは、ギリシャ文学の2大傑作であるイリアスとオデュッセイアを作曲した伝説の盲目詩人ホメロスでしょう。 ソフォクレスやアリストファネスは、今でも人気の劇作家であり、彼らの戯曲は世界文学の最高傑作と称えられています。 もう1人の有名なギリシャ人は数学者ピタゴラスで、主に直角三角形の辺の関係についての有名な定理を発見したことで知られています。

src: 中東の温暖な気候に暮らす人々にとって家屋はそれほど重要ではありませんでした。 ヘブライ人家族はほとんど戸外で暮らしていました。 女性たちが庭で調理をし、店はいずれも街路に面した屋台に過ぎませんでした。家の建築には石が使われていました。 カナンの地には大規模な森林が存在しなかったので木材は非常に高価で貴重なものでした。
mt: Homes were not as important to people living in the warm climate of the Middle East. Hebrew families lived mostly outdoors. Women cooked in the yard, and shops were mostly street vendors. Stone was used in the construction of homes. There were no large forests in Canaan, so wood was very expensive and precious.
ref: In the warm climate of the Middle East, the house was not so important. Most of the life of the Hebrew family happened in the open air. Women did the cooking in the yard; stores were just open counters looking into the street. Stone was used for building houses. There were no large forests in the land of Canaan, so wood was extremely expensive.

src: 中東の温暖な気候に暮らす人々にとって家屋はそれほど重要ではありませんでした。 ヘブライ人家族はほとんど戸外で暮らしていました。 女性たちが庭で調理をし、店はいずれも街路に面した屋台に過ぎませんでした。家の建築には石が使われていました。 カナンの地には大規模な森林が存在しなかったので木材は非常に高価で貴重なものでした。

src: グリーンランドは過疎な地域でした。北欧の伝承によれば、赤毛のエイリークが殺人罪でアイスランドから追放され、西に向かったときにグリーンランドを発見して、グリーンランドと名付けたとされます。 しかし、彼の発見とは関係なく、当時すでにエスキモー部族はそこに住んでいました。 どの国も「スカンジナビア」であることは変わりませんが、デンマーク、スウェーデン、ノルウェー、アイスランドの国民性、王制、風習、歴史には相当な違いがあったのです。
mt: Greenland was sparsely populated. According to Nordic tradition, Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder and sailed west, where he discovered Greenland and named it. However, his discovery was independent of the fact that the Inuit had already been living there. The nationalities, monarchies, customs, and histories of the "Scandinavian" countries of Denmark, Sweden, Norway, and Iceland were quite different.
ref: Greenland was settled sparsely. In the Norse sagas they say that Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder, and when travelling further west, found Greenland and named it Greenland. But regardless of his discovery, Eskimo tribes were already living there at the time. Though each country was 'Scandinavian', there were many differences between the people, kings, customs and history of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.

src: 彼らの食べ物のほとんどは私たちに馴染みのあるものですが、ローマ人はイノシシ、孔雀、カタツムリ、そしてネズミと呼ばれる齧歯類の一種など、下手物や珍味を食していました。 もう1つの違いは、貧しい人々や女性は椅子に座って食事をするのに対し、金持ちの男性は寝そべってくつろぎながら食事をする宴会を好んだということです。 古代ローマの食事には、後の数世紀の間にアメリカやアジアから欧州に渡ってきた食材が取り入れられたはずはありません。 例えば、そこにはトウモロコシもトマトもジャガイモもココアもなく、七面鳥を味わった古代ローマ人はいなかったわけです。
mt: Their food was mostly familiar to us, but the Romans ate exotic fare such as wild boar, peacocks, snails, and a species of rodent called the dormouse. Another difference was that the poor and women sat at tables to eat, while rich men reclined on couches to dine. Ancient Roman meals would not have included the foods that would later be brought to Europe from America and Asia. For example, there were no corn, tomatoes, potatoes, or cocoa, and the ancient Romans had never tasted turkey.
ref: While most of their food would be familiar to us, Romans did have their share of strange or unusual feast items, including wild boar, peacock, snails, and a type of rodent called a dormouse Another difference was that while the poor people and the woman ate their food while sitting in chairs, the rich men liked to have banquets together where they would lounge on their sides while they ate their meals. Ancient Roman meals couldn't have included foods that came to Europe from America or from Asia in later centuries. For instance, they didn't have corn, nor tomatoes, nor potatoes, nor cocoa, and no ancient Roman ever tasted a turkey.

src: 文明とは、共同で生活や仕事を営む人々の大集団が共有する1つの文化、つまり社会のことです。 文明という言葉は、市民を意味するラテン語の形容詞civilisから来ており、市民を意味するラテン語の名詞civis、都市や都市国家を意味し、何らかの形で社会の規模を定義するcivitasという名詞に関係しています。 都市国家は国家の前身です。文明文化とは、数世代にわたる知識の継承、文化的足跡の存続、公正な普及を意味します。 主流からはずれた文化は、正式な文明として認識されないまま消滅することが多く、そうすると歴史的証拠は残りません。
mt: 1. A civilization is a large group of people living together and sharing a common culture, that is, a society. The word civilization comes from the Latin adjective civilis, meaning "civil", and is related to the Latin noun civis, meaning "citizen", and civitas, meaning "city" or "city-state", which is the precursor of the nation-state. A civilization is a culture that has been passed down over several generations, that has cultural continuity, and that has been fairly widely disseminated. A culture that is outside the mainstream may not be recognized as a civilization and may disappear without leaving historical evidence.
ref: A civilization is a singular culture shared by a significant large group of people who live and work co-operatively, a society. The word civilization comes from the Latin civilis, meaning civil, related to the Latin civis, meaning citizen, and civitas, meaning city or city-state, and that also somehow defines the size of the society. City-states are the precursors of nations. A civilizational culture implies the passing on of knowledge across several generations, a lingering cultural footprint and fair dissemination. Minor cultures often vanish without leaving relevant historic evidence and fail to be recognized as proper civilizations.

src: ドゥルギャルゾンは、（フォンディ村の）パロ地区の高台にある廃墟となった要塞や仏教寺院です。 1649年にシャブドゥン・ガワン・ナムゲルがチベット・モンゴル軍との戦いに勝利したことを記念して、この要塞を建設したと言われています。 1951年の火災によりほとんどが焼失し、ジャブドゥルング・ガワン・ナムゲルの絵など、ドゥルギャルゾン遺跡の一部しか残りませんでした。 火災後の要塞は保存・保護され、今ではブータンで話題の観光名所の1つとして残っています。
mt: Drukgyal Dzong is located in the Paro district, on a hill above the ruined fortress and Buddhist temple. It is said to have been built in 1649 by Shabduun Gawaan Nampel to commemorate his victory over the Tibetan-Mongolian army. It was mostly destroyed by fire in 1951, and only part of the Drukgyal Dzong ruins remain, including a painting of Jhabduurung Gawaan Nampel. The ruined fortress is now a popular tourist attraction in Bhutan.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

src: ドゥルギャルゾンは、（フォンディ村の）パロ地区の高台にある廃墟となった要塞や仏教寺院です。 1649年にシャブドゥン・ガワン・ナムゲルがチベット・モンゴル軍との戦いに勝利したことを記念して、この要塞を建設したと言われています。 1951年の火災によりほとんどが焼失し、ジャブドゥルング・ガワン・ナムゲルの絵など、ドゥルギャルゾン遺跡の一部しか残りませんでした。 火災後の要塞は保存・保護され、今ではブータンで話題の観光名所の1つとして残っています。
mt: Drukgyal Dzong is located in the Paro district, on a hill above the ruined fortress and Buddhist temple. It is said to have been built in 1649 by Shabduun Gawaan Nampel to commemorate his victory over the Tibetan-Mongolian army. It was mostly destroyed by fire in 1951, and only part of the Drukgyal Dzong ruins remain, including a painting of Jhabduurung Gawaan Nampel. The ruined fortress is now a popular tourist attraction in Bhutan.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

src: 18世紀のカンボジアは、タイとベトナムという2つの強力な隣国に挟まれて苦しい立場にありました。 タイ人は18世紀に幾度もカンボジアに侵入し、1772年にはプノンフェンを破壊しました。 18世紀末にはベトナム人もカンボジアを侵略しました。
mt: 18th-century Cambodia was in a precarious position, sandwiched between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century, and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Penh. In the late 18th century, the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.
ref: During the 18th century Cambodia found itself squeezed between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Phen. In the last years of the 18th century the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.

src: 18世紀のカンボジアは、タイとベトナムという2つの強力な隣国に挟まれて苦しい立場にありました。 タイ人は18世紀に幾度もカンボジアに侵入し、1772年にはプノンフェンを破壊しました。 18世紀末にはベトナム人もカンボジアを侵略しました。
mt: 18th-century Cambodia was in a precarious position, sandwiched between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century, and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Penh. In the late 18th century, the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.
ref: During the 18th century Cambodia found itself squeezed between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Phen. In the last years of the 18th century the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.

src: 台湾の始まりは15世紀にヨーロッパの船乗りたちがこの島の名前を「イルハ・フォルモサ」（美しい島）と呼んだことから始まりました。 1624年、オランダの東インド会社が台湾南西部に拠点を置き、原住民の穀物生産方法を変革し、中国人労働者を雇って米や砂糖のプランテーションに従事させました。 1683年に清朝（1644～1912年）軍が台湾西部および北部の沿岸部を占領し、1885年に台湾を清国の省とすることを宣言しました。 1895年、第一次日清戦争（1894年～1895年）の敗戦後、清国政府は下関条約に調印し、台湾の主権を日本に譲りました。
mt: Taiwan's history began when European sailors called the island "Ilha Formosa" (beautiful island) in the 15th century. In 1624, the Dutch East India Company established a base in southwestern Taiwan and revolutionized the indigenous grain production methods, hiring Chinese laborers to work on rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing (1644-1912) army occupied the western and northern coastal areas of Taiwan, and in 1885, declared Taiwan a province of the Qing Empire. In 1895, after losing the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing government signed the Treaty of Shimonoseki and ceded Taiwan's sovereignty to Japan.
ref: Taiwan beginning start way back in 15th century where European sailors passing by record the island’s name as Ilha Formosa, or beautiful island. In 1624,Dutch East India Company establishes a base in southwestern Taiwan, initiating a transformation in aboriginal grain production practices and employing Chinese laborers to work on its rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing dynasty (1644-1912) forces take control of Taiwan’s western and northern coastal areas and declared Taiwan as a province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after defeat in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing government signs the Treaty of Shimonoseki, by which it cedes sovereignty over Taiwan to Japan, which rules the island until 1945.

src: これを化学物質のpHといいます。紫キャベツの絞り汁で試験紙を作ることができます。 キャベツの汁は化学物質に反応し、酸性かアルカリ性（塩基性）かによって色が変わります。 pH レベルは、検査した化学物質に含まれる水素イオン（pHのH）の量で示されます。 水素イオンとは、電子を取り除いた陽子のことです（水素原子は陽子と電子が1つずつで構成されているため）。
mt: This is called the pH of a chemical. You can make a pH test strip with purple cabbage juice. The cabbage juice reacts with chemicals and changes color depending on whether it is acidic or basic (alkaline). The pH level is shown by the amount of hydrogen ions (pH H) in the chemical tested. Hydrogen ions are positively charged protons (hydrogen atoms are made up of one proton and one electron).
ref: This is called a chemical's pH. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. The cabbage juice changes color depending on how acidic or basic (alkaline) the chemical is. The pH level is indicated by the amount of Hydrogen (the H in pH) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons that had their electrons stripped off them (since Hydrogen atoms consist of one proton and one electron).

src: ライオンは最も社交的なネコ科の動物であり、プライドと呼ばれる大集団で生活しています。 プライドは、1～3頭の血縁関係にあるオスと30頭余りのメスと子供たちで構成されます。 通常、メスたちは互いに血がつながっており、姉妹や娘からなる大家族を形成しています。 ライオンのプライドは、狼や犬の群れに似た行動を示し、動物は驚くほど行動のライオン（が、他の大きな猫）に似ていて、獲物を逃さずに仕留めます。
mt: Lions are the most social of cats, living in prides of up to three related males and 30 or more females and their young.  Typically, the females are related, forming sister or daughter matrilines.  Lion prides are similar in behavior to wolf or dog packs, and lions are surprisingly cooperative in hunting, taking down prey without losing any.
ref: Lions are the most social cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides are made up of one to three related adult males, along with as many as thirty females and cubs. The females are usually closely related to each other, being a large family of sisters and daughters. Lion prides act much like packs of wolves or dogs, animals surprisingly similar to lions (but not other big cats) in behavior, and also very deadly to their prey.

src: その下には、ウサギからカモシカや鹿までの中型の獲物を食べる中型の猫類が多くなります。 最後に、昆虫、げっ歯類、トカゲ、鳥といったはるかに多数の小さい獲物を餌とする小型の猫（野良猫を含む）が数多く生息しています。 その成功の秘訣はニッチという概念であり、猫ごとに特別な仕事があり、他の猫と競合しないようにするということです。
mt: Below them are the medium-sized predators that eat medium-sized prey such as rabbits, deer, and foxes.  Finally, there are the small predators that eat many more tiny prey such as insects, rodents, lizards, and birds, including feral cats.  The secret to their success is the concept of niche, where each cat has a special job and does not compete with other cats.
ref: Under them are more medium sized cats that eat medium sized prey ranging from rabbits to antelopes and deer. Finally, there are many small cats (including loose pet cats) that eat the far more numerous small prey like insects, rodents, lizards, and birds. The secret to their success is the concept of the niche, a special job each cat holds that keeps it from competing with others.

src: オセロットは小動物を好んで食べます。猿や蛇、げっ歯類、鳥類なども可能であれば捕まえます。オセロットが狩る獲物のほとんどは、自分よりもはるかに小さい生き物です。 科学者たちは、オセロットは地面の匂いを嗅いで餌になる動物（獲物）が通った場所を探し、追いかけると考えています。 高い暗視能力で非常に夜目が効き、こっそりと移動するのも得意です。オセロットは周囲に溶け込み、獲物に飛びかかって狩りをします。
mt: Ocelots are carnivores. They eat monkeys, snakes, rodents, birds, and other small animals. Scientists think that ocelots hunt by sniffing the ground for the scent of prey that has passed by. They are very good at moving quietly and have excellent night vision. Ocelots blend in with their surroundings and pounce on their prey.
ref: Ocelots like to eat small animals. They will catch monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds if they can. Almost all of the animals that the ocelot hunts are far smaller than it is. Scientists think that ocelots follow and find animals to eat (prey) by smell, sniffing for where they've been on the ground. They can see very well in the dark with night vision, and move very stealthily, too. Ocelots hunt their prey by blending in with their surroundings then pouncing on their prey.

src: 実に均整の取れた体で運動能力の高い虎は、（うまくはないものの）登ったり、泳いだり、長い距離を跳んだり、たくましい人間の5倍の力で引っ張ったりできます。 トラはライオン、ヒョウ、ジャガーと同じ動物群（ヒョウ属）に属しています。唸ることができるのはこの4種類の大型ネコ科の動物だけです。 虎の咆哮は、ライオンのような雄叫びではなく、どちらかというと威圧的な脅し文句のような咆哮です。
mt: Tigers are well-proportioned and have excellent athletic abilities. They can climb, swim, jump long distances, and pull with five times the strength of a man. Tigers are part of the Panthera genus, which also includes lions, leopards, and jaguars. Only these four large cats can roar. A tiger's roar is not a lion-like roar, but more of a threatening growl.
ref: A well rounded athlete, the tiger can climb (though not well), swim, leap great distances and pull with five times the force of a strong human. The tiger is in the same group (Genus Panthera) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These four cats are the only ones who can roar. The tiger's roar is not like the full-voiced roar of a lion, but more like a sentence of snarly, shouted words.

src: 細胞とは生物の構造的機能的な最小単位です。 セルはラテン語で小さな部屋を意味する「cella」に由来しています。 生物を顕微鏡で見ると、丸や四角の微細な組織でできていることがわかります。 英国の自然哲学者ロバート・フックは、顕微鏡でコルクの切片を観察し、たくさんの小部屋が見えることを確認しました。 見た目はいくつもの部屋のようでした。彼は死んだ細胞を観察した最初の人でした。
mt: Cells are the structural and functional basic units of an organism. The word cell comes from the Latin cella, meaning small room. When looking at a biological organism under a microscope, one can see that it is made up of many small, round or square structures. Robert Hooke was the first person to observe dead cells under a microscope. He observed that they looked like many rooms.
ref: A cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of a living (things) organism. Cell comes from the Latin word cella which means small room. If you look at living things under a microscope, you will see that they are made of small squares or balls. Robert Hooke, a biologist from England, saw small squares in cork with a microscope. They looked like rooms. He was the first person to observe dead cells

src: 動物の体は多数の細胞でできています。動物は食物を摂取して体内で消化します。ほとんどの動物は動くことができます。 脳を持っているのは動物だけです（すべての動物が持っているわけではなく、クラゲなどは持っていません）。 動物は地球上のいたるところに生息しています。地面を掘ったり、海を泳ぎ回ったり、空を飛んだりしています。
mt: Animals are made up of many cells. Animals eat food and digest it inside their bodies. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (not all animals have them, like jellyfish). Animals live all over the Earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the sea, and fly in the air.
ref: Animals are made of many cells. They eat things and digest them inside. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (though not even all animals do; jellyfish, for example, do not have brains). Animals are found all over the earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky.

src: 植物は人間が吸う酸素を作り、人間が（息として）吐き出す二酸化炭素を取り込んでいます。 植物は光合成によって太陽から養分を作りだします。日陰も作ってくれます。 私たちは植物で家を造り、植物から衣類を作ります。日々食べる食材の多くが植物です。植物がなければ動物は生きていけません。
mt: Plants make oxygen for humans to breathe and take in the carbon dioxide that humans exhale. Plants make nutrients from the sun through photosynthesis. They also make shade. We build houses with plants and make clothes from plants. Many of the foods we eat every day are plants. Without plants, animals cannot live.
ref: Plants make oxygen which humans breathe, and they take in carbon-dioxide which humans exhale (that is, breathe out). Plants make their food from the sun by photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

We build houses with plants and make clothes from plants. Many of the foods we eat every day are plants. Without plants, animals cannot live.
ref: Plants make oxygen which humans breathe, and they take in carbon-dioxide which humans exhale (that is, breathe out). Plants make their food from the sun by photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

src: 生き物の小集団（少ない個体数）が、所属していた大集団から離れて（例えば、山脈や川を越えて移動したり、簡単には戻れないような新しい島に移動して）しまうと、多くの場合、以前とは異なる環境にいることに気づくことになります。 この新しい環境には、異なる資源と異なる競争相手が存在するため、新しい集団にはそれまで必要だったものとは異なる特徴や適応が必要となり、強力な競争相手となる可能性があります。 元の集団は全く変わっておらず、今でも昔と同じように適応を必要としています。 新しい集団が新しい環境に適応し始めると、時間の経過とともに、他の集団とは異なる様相を呈し始めます。 最終的には、数千年から数百万年後に2つの個体群は同一種とは呼べないほど異なる外観になるでしょう。 このプロセスを種形成と呼びますが、これは単に新しい種の形成を意味しています。種形成は避けられない結果であり、非常に重要な進化の部分です。
mt: When a small group of organisms (a small number of individuals) separates from the larger group (for example, by moving over a mountain or river, or by moving to a new island that is difficult to return to), they often become aware that they are in a different environment than before. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new group may need different characteristics and adaptations than before, and may become a strong competitor. The original group remains unchanged, and still needs the same adaptations as before. As the new group begins to adapt to the new environment, over time, it begins to take on a different appearance from the other group. Eventually, after thousands to hundreds of millions of years, the two groups will be so different that they cannot be called the same species. This process is called speciation, and it means the formation of a new species. Speciation is an inevitable result, and is an important part of evolution.
ref: When a small group of living things (a small population) gets separated from the main population that they came from (like if they move over a mountain range or a river, or if they move to a new island so that they can't easily move back) they will often find themselves in a different environment than they were in before. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population will need different features or adaptations to be a strong competitor than what they had needed before. The original population hasn't changed at all, they still need the same adaptations as before. Over time, as the new population begins to adapt to their new environment, they start to look less and less like the other population. Eventually, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they can't be called the same species. We call this process speciation, which just means the formation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

src: 循環器系の主要器官は心臓であり、血液を送り出す役割を果たす臓器です。 血液は、動脈と呼ばれる管を通って心臓から送り出され、静脈と呼ばれる管を通って心臓に戻ります。最小の管は毛細血管と呼ばれます。
mt: The major organs of the circulatory system are the heart, which pumps blood, and the blood vessels, which carry it. The smallest blood vessels are called capillaries.
ref: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps the blood. Blood goes away from the heart in tubes called arteries and comes back to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.

src: 循環器系の主要器官は心臓であり、血液を送り出す役割を果たす臓器です。 血液は、動脈と呼ばれる管を通って心臓から送り出され、静脈と呼ばれる管を通って心臓に戻ります。最小の管は毛細血管と呼ばれます。
mt: The major organs of the circulatory system are the heart, which pumps blood, and the blood vessels, which carry it. The smallest blood vessels are called capillaries.
ref: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps the blood. Blood goes away from the heart in tubes called arteries and comes back to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.

src: 昆虫は空を飛んだ最初の動物でした。空を飛ぶ能力は、敵を回避したり、餌や仲間を効率よく見つけるのに役立ちました。 ほとんどの昆虫は、体に沿って翅を折り返すことができるようになっています。 これにより、捕食者から身を隠すための狭い場所の幅が広がります。 現在、翅を折り返すことができない昆虫はトンボとカゲロウのみです。
mt: Insects were the first animals to fly through the air. The ability to fly helped them avoid predators, find food and mates more efficiently. Most insects have wings that fold along their body. This allows them to hide in narrow places from predators. Currently, only dragonflies and mayflies cannot fold their wings.
ref: Insects were the first animals to take to the air. Their ability to fly helped them evade enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back along the body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold back their wings are dragon flies and mayflies.

src: 昆虫は空を飛んだ最初の動物でした。空を飛ぶ能力は、敵を回避したり、餌や仲間を効率よく見つけるのに役立ちました。 ほとんどの昆虫は、体に沿って翅を折り返すことができるようになっています。 これにより、捕食者から身を隠すための狭い場所の幅が広がります。 現在、翅を折り返すことができない昆虫はトンボとカゲロウのみです。

src: 今日、多くの古生物学者は、あるグループの恐竜が生き残り、現在も生きていると信じています。私たちはそれを鳥と呼んでいます。 羽を持ち、空を飛べるので、恐竜だと思っていない人も大勢います。 しかし、現在も鳥の外観は多くの点で恐竜に似ています。 鱗と爪のついた足を持ち、卵胎生であり、ティラノサウルスのように後ろ脚2本で歩きます。
mt: Today, many paleontologists believe that a group of dinosaurs survived and are still living. We call them birds. There are many people who do not think they are dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. However, the appearance of birds is still similar to dinosaurs in many ways. They have scales and claws on their feet, lay eggs, and walk on two back legs like a Tyrannosaurus.
ref: Many paleontologists today believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and is alive today. We call them birds. Many people don't think about them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have feet with scales and claws, they lay eggs, and they walk on their two back legs like a T-Rex.

src: 今日、多くの古生物学者は、あるグループの恐竜が生き残り、現在も生きていると信じています。私たちはそれを鳥と呼んでいます。 羽を持ち、空を飛べるので、恐竜だと思っていない人も大勢います。 しかし、現在も鳥の外観は多くの点で恐竜に似ています。 鱗と爪のついた足を持ち、卵胎生であり、ティラノサウルスのように後ろ脚2本で歩きます。

There are many people who do not think they are dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. However, the appearance of birds is still similar to dinosaurs in many ways. They have scales and claws on their feet, lay eggs, and walk on two back legs like a Tyrannosaurus.
ref: Many paleontologists today believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and is alive today. We call them birds. Many people don't think about them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have feet with scales and claws, they lay eggs, and they walk on their two back legs like a T-Rex.

src: トリケラトプスの歯は、木の葉のみでなく、硬い枝や根をも噛み砕くことができたのでしょう。 科学者の中には、トリケラトプスが白亜紀に多く自生していたソテツ類の植物を食べたと考えている人もいる。 これらの植物は、鋭く尖った冠状の葉を持ち、外観はヤシに似た低木です。 トリケラトプスは木の幹を食べる前に、その強靭なくちばしで葉をはぎ取っていた可能性があります。 他の科学者たちは、これらの植物は極めて毒性が高いため、今日ナマケモノや他の（恐竜の子孫である）オウムのような動物が毒のある葉や果実を食べることができるにもかかわらず、どの恐竜もそれらを食べていた可能性は低いと主張しています。
mt: The teeth of Triceratops could have crushed not only leaves, but also hard branches and roots. Some scientists think that Triceratops ate the coniferous plants that were common in the Cretaceous. These plants had pointed, crown-shaped leaves and looked like palms. Triceratops may have stripped the leaves off the trunk before eating it with its strong beak. Other scientists argue that these plants were so toxic that no dinosaur could have eaten them, even though today monkeys and other (dinosaur descendants) birds can eat toxic leaves and fruits.
ref: A triceratops' teeth would have been able to crush not only leaves but even very tough branches and roots. Some scientists think Triceratops ate cycads, which are a type of plant that was common in the Cretaceous. These plants look like a small palm tree with a crown of sharp, spiky leaves. A Triceratops could have used its strong beak to strip off the leaves before eating the trunk. Other scientists argue that these plants are very poisonous so it is unlikely that any dinosaur ate them, even though today the sloth and other animals like the parrot (a descendant of the dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.
